challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: BloomWatch: An Earth Observation Application for Global Flowering Phenology
challengeDetails.excerpt: Witness the pulse of life across our planet! From season to season and year to year, Earth’s vegetation is constantly changing, providing critical information on plant species, crops, seasonal effects, pollen sources, and changes in plant phenology (the relationship between seasonal changes and climate and biological phenomena in plants). Your challenge is to harness the power of NASA Earth observations to create a dynamic visual tool that displays and/or detects plant blooming events around the globe—just like pollinators do–and that advances solutions for monitoring, predicting, or managing vegetation. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Embiggen Your Eyes!
challengeDetails.excerpt: While your cell phone screen can display about three million pixels of information and your eye can receive more than ten million pixels, NASA images from space are even bigger! NASA’s space missions continue to push the boundaries of what is technologically possible, providing high-resolution images and videos of Earth, other planets, and space with billions or even trillions of pixels. Your challenge is to create a platform that allows users to zoom in and out on these massive image datasets, label known features, and discover new patterns. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Guardions Of Jalapão
projectDetails.summary:
We are the Alpha Mackenzie team, Brazilian middle school students, and we developed the project "Guardians of Jalapão," which addresses the favorable Brazilian climate conditions for harvesting Golden Grass. Inspired by the proposed challenge and the Golden Grass Women's Project, which uses sustainable agricultural practices for the production and harvesting of golden grass, our goal was to develop an educational game to raise awareness about the importance of such initiatives that use natural resources through sustainable management based on ideal climate conditions.

Therefore, the relevance of this project lies in simulating a resource collection scenario (temperature, precipitation, and soil moisture) and providing players with information about the correct and ideal management of golden grass harvesting. This game is intended to be made available to students as a way to raise awareness about sustainability and proper golden grass management. Additionally, it could be displayed in museums and at the headquarters of the Golden Grass Women's Project to highlight the ideal conditions and the consequences of resource collection according to the seasons.
projectDetails.details:
We are the Alpha Mackenzie team, and our project, "Guardians of Jalapão," is aligned with Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 15, which focuses on life on land. That’s why we chose to work with Golden Grass — a resource widely used in the Jalapão region for the production of handicrafts that generate income for local communities — by understanding the most favorable climate conditions for its growth and harvest.

We developed a game using the tools available on Scratch, with the main purpose of raising awareness about the harvesting of Golden Grass in the Jalapão region, based on the climate characteristics we researched and how they affect the collection of this resource. The game’s primary goal is to promote awareness about the extraction of Golden Grass and how it grows throughout the seasons of the year. It serves as a tool to present the data and information collected, helping the public understand and become more conscious of this issue.

Golden Grass (Syngonanthus nitens) is a plant native to the Brazilian Cerrado, especially found in Jalapão (Tocantins state). It is used to make handicrafts that symbolize the local culture, such as bags and jewelry. Its sustainable harvesting is regulated by the Tocantins Nature Institute (Naturatins) to ensure the conservation of the species. The grass is harvested annually after the seeds mature.

We collected data using Google Earth Engine and selected the Jalapão region, where Golden Grass is most abundantly produced. Additionally, we uploaded a script with commands to retrieve climate characteristics such as temperature, precipitation, and soil moisture from last year (2024). Our main focus was on precipitation and temperature.

Based on this information, we identified the climate characteristics and associated them with their impact on the production and harvesting of Golden Grass, allowing us to understand the reactions caused by these factors. The game uses this data to show the player what happens depending on the amount of resources collected during gameplay.

"Guardians of Jalapão" runs, as mentioned earlier, on Scratch — a free, open-source visual programming language developed at MIT to teach coding in a fun and accessible way. The user will access a link that redirects them to the game on Scratch. In the game, the player controls a character and collects clouds (precipitation), a thermometer (temperature), and a soil bar (soil moisture). Depending on the number of items the user collects, the outcome will change according to the climate conditions of Jalapão for each season.

The ideal time for the player to achieve the best result is during spring, as it is the favorable season for harvesting Golden Grass in the region — a dry and arid period. If the user collects values that differ from the ideal, the game will inform them of the current season and its impact on the Golden Grass.

With this project, we aim to show how closely climate characteristics are linked to the development and harvesting of Golden Grass — a vital resource for income generation in the Jalapão region. Furthermore, one of our goals is to bring the game to museums in the Cerrado region, especially those that focus on this biome, or to communities that work with this resource, particularly the "Golden Grass Women's Project." There, tourists could learn about the differences in Brazil’s seasons and how they affect the harvesting of this plant. In this way, the game could be commercialized and made available for use in these locations (museums and community centers).

Therefore, the target audience for the game includes the communities that work with Golden Grass, organizations or institutions that deal with this resource or the Cerrado biome, and tourists visiting the aforementioned locations.

For the development of our project, we used the following technologies:

Scratch: A visual programming platform and block-based coding language that allows users to create games, animations, and interactive stories by dragging and dropping visual commands instead of writing complex code — used for creating the game developed by the team.

Google Earth Engine (a tool recommended by NASA): A geospatial data science platform that provides a massive catalog of satellite imagery and geographic data, along with cloud computing infrastructure for planetary-scale analysis — used for collecting, comparing, and analyzing climate data.

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. projectDetails.name: Project Angelus Novus
projectDetails.summary:
For the challenge NASA Farm Navigators: Using NASA Data Exploration in Agriculture, we developed Farm Navigators, an educational strategy card game designed to make complex Earth science data accessible and engaging. Players take the role of agricultural decision-makers, balancing four pillars — Economy, Sustainability, Technology, and People — while making choices about irrigation, fertilization, and livestock management. Each decision carries trade-offs, teaching that agriculture involves dilemmas rather than perfect solutions.

Our game integrates real NASA datasets: NDVI/EVI (MODIS & Landsat) to monitor vegetation health, SMAP for soil moisture, GPM for precipitation, and MODIS LST for land surface temperature. These datasets inform the scenarios presented in the cards, grounding decisions in real-world science.

To enrich the narrative, we created Little Eliot, an AI Agent acting as a Narrative Consequence Analyst. Eliot provides short, subtly ironic reflections on each decision and, at the end of the game, the player’s results are added to a shared database. This allows participants to compare outcomes, fostering collective learning and a sense of responsibility for the world.
projectDetails.details:
Project Details – Farm Navigators

What it does / how it works
Farm Navigators is an educational strategy card game that simulates real farming decisions using NASA’s open datasets. Players must balance four pillars — Economy, Sustainability, Technology, and People — while managing irrigation, fertilization, and livestock. Each choice triggers trade-offs, showing that agriculture is a world of dilemmas rather than perfect solutions.

Benefits & Intended Impact
The game makes complex NASA Earth data accessible and engaging, helping players of all ages understand how environmental variables affect food production, sustainability, and social well-being. By linking real satellite data to everyday farming scenarios, it promotes climate awareness, sustainable practices, and data-driven thinking. The collective database of player results encourages reflection on global responsibility, as participants can compare whether their choices “helped or harmed the world.”

AI Integration – Little Eliot
We created Little Eliot, an AI Agent acting as a Narrative Consequence Analyst. After each decision, Eliot generates short, subtly ironic commentaries suggesting possible futures. At the end, progress is recorded in a shared database, fostering a sense of community and collective learning.

Tools, Languages, and Frameworks
We combined modern tools to develop the project:

  • Lovable, Langflow, Cursor – for AI workflows and prototyping.
  • React & TypeScript – for the front-end interface.
  • FastAPI & MongoDB – for backend logic and database storage.
  • ChatGPT-5 nano – powering Eliot’s generative AI responses.

Creativity & Design Considerations
We designed Farm Navigators to merge serious data with playful storytelling, blending strategy, education, and irony. Our key considerations were scientific accuracy, player engagement, and scalability, ensuring the game can grow into classrooms, communities, and global platforms.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

Our project makes purposeful use of AI in both its game design and technical development:

  1. Narrative Gameplay – Little Eliot
    • We created Little Eliot, an AI Agent acting as a Narrative Consequence Analyst.
    • Eliot uses a fine-tuned prompt with ChatGPT-5 nano to generate short, subtly ironic narrative commentaries after each player decision.
    • These outputs enrich the storytelling by suggesting possible consequences without referencing scores or game mechanics.
    • We used AI-assisted tools (such as Langflow, Cursor, and Lovable) to accelerate prototyping, workflow orchestration, and prompt optimization.
    • Draft texts, gameplay scenarios, and narrative examples were initially generated with AI, then refined by our team.
    • All AI-generated texts were reviewed and edited to align with the project’s educational goals.
    • Portions of boilerplate code and database handling were generated using AI tools to speed up development.
    • Metadata and documentation acknowledge AI contributions.

Compliance Measures

  • No NASA logos, mission identifiers, or official branding were generated or modified by AI.
  • Any AI-generated visuals or audio (if used in later stages) will carry visible AI-generated watermarks and proper metadata acknowledgments.

Through this integration, AI was not used to replace originality but to accelerate creativity, enhance gameplay, and prototype faster while keeping the final vision and design firmly in the hands of our team.

projectDetails.name: Transform(ação) de Territórios
projectDetails.summary:
A Transform(ação) de Territórios é um aplicativo que se alinha diretamente ao desafio da NASA, "Caminhos de Dados para Cidades Saudáveis e Assentamentos Humanos". Combatemos o Racismo Ambiental ao expor a concentração desproporcional de riscos ambientais (poluição, falta de saneamento) e a negação de serviços essenciais em comunidades negras e de baixa renda. Transformamos essas comunidades em agentes ativos de defesa territorial. 
O pilar de Monitoramento e Denúncia é crucial para o objetivo da NASA. Usuários, como "Sentinelas Ambientais", criam um "Mapa de Conflitos" em tempo real via geolocalização e mídias verificadas. Geramos dados de nível de rua que fornecem o contexto social e humano vital que está ausente nas observações globais por satélite. Ao cruzar estas informações, fornecemos o elo perdido entre o monitoramento da ciência da Terra e a realidade da saúde urbana. 
Com Educação continuada sobre direitos, capacitamos a autodefesa. As denúncias geram evidências jurídicas inegáveis para a Pressão Institucional, roteadas para as autoridades competentes. 
O slogan "Onde a poluição tem endereço, a justiça tem voz", resume a missão de transformar a luta social em Justiça Ambiental efetiva, entregando os caminhos de dados necessários para construir cidades verdadeiramente saudáveis e equitativas.
projectDetails.details:
O aplicativo de Combate ao Racismo Ambiental, embora focado em comunidades específicas, geram impactos significativos que alcançam o planeta e até mesmo a NASA (agência espacial dos EUA, conhecida por seu trabalho em ciência da Terra e monitoramento global). Impacto e importância para o Planeta (Meio Ambiente Global).

O aplicativo contribui diretamente para a saúde do planeta ao combater as fontes de degradação ambiental que geralmente são invisíveis nas estatísticas oficiais, como geração de dados de baixo nível para o clima: a poluição registrada pelas comunidades (lixões, esgotos não tratados, vazamentos químicos) é uma fonte significativa de gases para o efeito estufa (como o metano) e contaminantes. Ao mapear essas fontes com precisão, o aplicativo fornece dados essenciais para mitigação do clima, ajuda a identificar e remover focos de contaminação que contribuem para as mudanças climáticas. Justiça Climática sendo a luta contra o racismo ambiental é, fundamental, uma luta por justiça climática, garantindo que a adaptação e a mitigação sejam priorizadas nas comunidades mais vulneráveis.

Monitoramento da biodiversidade e da água, abrindo denúncias sobre o desmatamento, invasão de terras e contaminação de rios por comunidades ribeirinhas ou indígenas alimentam banco de dados sobre a saúde dos ecossistemas. A poluição registrada localmente tem um efeito cascata em bacias hidrográficas e ecossistemas inteiros. ODS e Agenda Global também são parte, já que os dados do aplicativo apoiam diretamente vários dos Objetivos de Desenvolvimento Sustentável (ODS) da ONU, especialmente o ODS 10 (Redução das Desigualdades), ODS 11 (Cidades e Comunidades Sustentáveis) e ODS 16 (Paz, Justiça e Instituições Eficazes). Impacto e Importância para a NASA (Ciência da Terra).

A NASA é uma líder mundial em Ciência da Terra, utilizando satélites para monitorar a saúde do planeta. O aplicativo é crucial no conceito de "Validação de Campo" e "Ciência Cidadã"; Validação de Dados de Satélite, a NASA usa satélites (como os da constelação Sentinel, ou os de medição de gases atmosféricos) para identificar grandes áreas de desmatamento, incêndios ou focos de metano. O aplicativo atua como uma "Lente de Aumento Comunitária", as denúncias georeferênciadas dos moradores verificam e confirmam o que os satélites registram. Por exemplo, um sensor de satélite pode detectar um foco de poluição no ar, mas a denúncia da comunidade (Com foto e testemunho), diz se é um lixão ilegal, uma indústria que opera sem licença ou uma queimada intencional.

Preenchendo a lacuna intangível: a importância mais crítica para a NASA é que o aplicativo fornece dados sobre o que é intangível para a tecnologia espacial. Enquanto os satélites medem a poluição, eles não conseguem medir a falta de recursos, a negação de serviços ou o acesso limitado que tornam as comunidades vulneráveis. O aplicativo documenta a injustiça social - a falta de acesso à saúde, segurança e saneamento - provando a correlação entre a degradação ambiental e a omissão do Estado.

Geração de dados de baixa altitude: Satélites são excelentes para medições amplas (alta altitude), mas tem dificuldades de medir poluentes e riscos em nível de rua ou dentro de microclimas urbanos. Os dados do aplicativo integrados com sensores comunitários de baixo custo (a funcionalidade de IoT), fornecem dados de alta resolução (onde o problema está exatamente) que são vitais para modelos mais precisos de dispersão de poluentes atmosféricos e da água.

Combate ao efeito "Nuvem" e Visibilidade do Risco: Muitas comunidades afetadas por poluição tóxica vivem sob o "efeito nuvem" - a poluição física no ar que bloqueia a visão dos satélites (nuvem de fumaça de incêndios, névoa de indústrias). O aplicativo ao documentar o problema por baixo, complementa o monitoramento da NASA, preenchendo as lacunas e garantindo que o sofrimento humano e a degradação ambiental no chão não fiquem escondidos.

Este projeto é construído com um stack moderno e robusto para desenvolvimento web.

Framework Principal: Next.js (utilizando o App Router e React Server Components).

Linguagem: TypeScript.

Estilização: Tailwind CSS para estilização utilitária e responsiva.

Componentes de UI: ShadCN UI para um conjunto de componentes acessíveis e reutilizáveis.

Mapas:

Leaflet: Biblioteca de código aberto para mapas interativos.

React-Leaflet: Integração do Leaflet com o React.

Gráficos: Recharts para a criação de gráficos composable com React.

Ícones: Lucide React para ícones leves e consistentes.

Inteligência Artificial Generativa: Genkit (integrado, mas ainda não implementado nas funcionalidades visíveis).

Backend e Hospedagem: Firebase (configurado para App Hosting).

Em suma, o aplicativo faz a ponte entre a justiça social, a ciência espacial de ponta e a realidade vivida no chão, transformando a voz da comunidade em dados verificáveis e de importância global, complementando as informações da NASA ao dar contexto social e humano aos seus registros ambientais. Um plano criativo e inovador em suas vertentes e tema, considerando que o assunto (racismo ambiental) tem apenas 2 anos de validação científica, visando o desenvolvimento atual e futuro socioambiental, comunitário e global.
projectDetails.aiReferences: IAs foram utilizadas em todo o processo, desde a coleta de dados sobre o que é o Racismo Ambiental, enquanto suporte de para as pesquisas. Também foram utilizadas para o Desenvolvimento de Protótipo e Codificação, Arquitetura de Dados e Plataforma, Design de Interface do Usuário e conteúdo do app, Estratégia e Comunicação.

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: EarthShield25 — Simulated Asteroid Mitigation
projectDetails.summary:
EarthShield25 is an interactive web platform designed to address the “Meteor Madness” challenge by simulating the potential impacts of Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) using real NASA data. The project integrates the NASA NeoWs API to retrieve updated asteroid information and combines it with geospatial layers and scientific models to calculate impact energy, crater size, seismic magnitude, and affected zones such as thermal and pressure radii.

Through an intuitive interface built with Leaflet.js and Chart.js, users can select an asteroid or input custom parameters to visualize the consequences of an impact on specific geographic regions. The tool also introduces educational features, helping the public, students, and decision-makers better understand asteroid threats and mitigation strategies.

By transforming complex astrophysical and geophysical data into accessible visualizations, EarthShield25 highlights the importance of planetary defense while promoting scientific literacy. This project demonstrates how open NASA datasets can empower communities to prepare for future scenarios and foster global collaboration in space science and disaster resilience.
projectDetails.details:
EarthShield25 is an interactive web platform designed to simulate and visualize the potential consequences of asteroid impacts on Earth. Using real data from NASA’s Near-Earth Object Web Service (NeoWs), the tool provides accurate information about asteroid trajectories, sizes, and velocities. Users can select an asteroid or input custom parameters and instantly see the simulated effects on a map, including crater formation, seismic activity, thermal radiation, shockwave radius, and potential tsunami risk.

The primary benefit of EarthShield25 is its ability to make complex scientific models accessible to a wide audience, from researchers and decision-makers to students and the general public. By transforming raw space data into interactive simulations, the project helps raise awareness of planetary defense challenges and supports education in space science and disaster preparedness.

The project was developed using JavaScript, HTML5, CSS3, Leaflet.js, and Netlify for deployment. Data visualization and physics models are integrated into the simulation engine, with a Node.js backend to handle API communication and environment variables securely.

Creativity comes from combining authentic NASA data with an engaging, gamified interface where users can not only explore impact scenarios but also test mitigation strategies (such as asteroid deflection). The project emphasizes accessibility with bilingual support (English and Portuguese) and clear explanations of technical terms to reach both experts and non-experts.

Our team considered usability, scientific reliability, and educational value as the main factors. The result is a platform that bridges the gap between scientific knowledge and public understanding, promoting global awareness and preparedness for asteroid threats.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
We used AI tools in the following ways for the EarthShield25 project:

  • Images and Icons: The main logo, favicon, and some asteroid/impact icons were generated with the assistance of AI image generation tools (ChatGPT/DALL·E). All AI-generated images include an indication in the README file and project documentation.
  • Code Assistance: AI (ChatGPT) was used to support code refactoring, debugging, and optimization of JavaScript functions for API integration and infinite scrolling. All final implementations were reviewed, tested, and validated by the development team.
  • Documentation: AI was also used to assist in drafting and translating descriptive text, including the English README and submission materials, which were later reviewed and finalized by the team.

AI was applied as a support tool to accelerate development and enhance clarity, while all creative, design, and technical decisions were made by the team.

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

projectDetails.name: ExoData AI
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, the Exoplanet Detector AI, directly addresses the challenge of manually analyzing vast astronomical data by providing a comprehensive, AI-powered web platform. We developed a high-accuracy (98.46%) XGBoost machine learning model, trained on unified open-source data from NASA's Kepler, K2, and TESS missions, to automatically classify exoplanet candidates.

Our solution is not just a model, but an interactive tool where users can upload new data or enter parameters manually for instant classification. Furthermore, it serves as an educational hub with a data analysis dashboard for visualizing the dataset and a detailed reference guide explaining the science behind exoplanets and our AI pipeline.

This is important because it democratizes access to complex astronomical data, saves researchers valuable time by efficiently filtering out false positives, and ultimately accelerates the discovery of new worlds.
projectDetails.details:
Our project, the ExoData AI, is a comprehensive web platform designed to accelerate the discovery of exoplanets. It works in two main parts: The AI Engine (Backend): At its core is a powerful XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosting) machine learning model, pre-trained on a unified dataset from NASA's Kepler, K2, and TESS missions. This AI engine follows a rigorous Machine Learning Pipeline: when it receives new data about a potential exoplanet, it automatically handles missing values (imputation), normalizes the data to a consistent scale (scaling), and then feeds it to the trained model to generate a classification ('Candidate', 'Confirmed', or 'False Positive') with a high degree of accuracy (98.46%).

The benefits and intended impact of our project are multi-faceted:

Acceleration of Scientific Discovery: By automating the classification of exoplanet candidates with high accuracy, our tool drastically reduces the manual labor required by astronomers. This allows them to focus their time and resources on the most promising signals, directly speeding up the process of confirming new worlds.

Increased Efficiency: The AI is highly effective at identifying 'False Positives', preventing valuable telescope time from being wasted on signals caused by instrumental noise or other astrophysical phenomena.

Our project was developed entirely with open-source tools on standard computer hardware.

Programming Language: Python

Web Framework: Streamlit

Pandas, Scikit-learn, Imblearn, XGBoost, Matplotlib, Seaborn

Development Environment: Jupyter Notebook for model training and experimentation; Visual Studio Code for application development.

Version Control & Deployment: Git & GitHub for version control; Streamlit Community Cloud for deployment.

SITE: https://binarybitsai.streamlit.app/

GITHUB: https://github.com/gasbriel07sm/hackathon_exoplanet

PRESENTATION: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1tML0y7xdS7ZsoGhZMpWzUZGGZPHVVHVd/view?usp=sharing
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Our project utilizes Artificial Intelligence in two distinct ways:

Data and Training: The model was trained on a unified dataset from NASA's Kepler, K2, and TESS missions. We designed and executed a complete machine learning pipeline, including data cleaning, feature engineering, handling class imbalance with SMOTE, and hyperparameter tuning, all documented in our Jupyter Notebook

Function: This is the "brain" of our application. Its function is to analyze astronomical data and classify exoplanet candidates as 'Candidate', 'Confirmed', or 'False Positive' with 98.46% accuracy. This AI is the direct solution to the challenge.

AI as a Development Tool (Assistance): To accelerate development and innovation, we utilized a Large Language Model (LLM) as a programming and writing assistant throughout the project. The LLM's role was to support our team, not to create the core logic or concept. Its specific uses include.

  • Documentation: Helping to generate summaries and detailed descriptions for the project submission forms.

projectDetails.name: Interactive Space Atlas
projectDetails.summary:
As imagens espaciais são importantes para melhor entendimento de fenômenos cósmicos e terrestres, e compreensão dos elementos que compõem nosso Sistema Solar e Universo. Com os avanços tecnológicos na captura e manipulação de imagens e vídeos, surge a necessidade de ferramentas mais eficientes. Nosso projeto desenvolvido com a combinação de HTML e JavaScript, apresenta um programa web para ampliar, comparar e caracterizar as imagens capturadas por satélites da NASA de forma interativa, ajudando pesquisadores e curiosos a identificar padrões na Terra e no espaço.   
Abordamos o desafio quando nosso principal objetivo é facilitar a exploração dos dados fornecidos pela NASA, e o acesso pelo público geral e as comunidades científicas. Além de estimular o interesse do público para nosso Universo através da exploração dinâmica.
projectDetails.details:
Como ele funciona?

O Interactive Space Atlas (ISA) permite que os usuários naveguem, analisem e comparem corpos celestes utilizando dados visuais de alta resolução gerados pelas missões espaciais e terrestres da NASA. Além de proporcionar uma visualização detalhada, o site oferece ferramentas como zoom, comparação temporal e identificação de características nas imagens. Com foco na performance, garantimos uma navegação fluida, permitindo ampliar e reduzir as imagens sem comprometer a velocidade ou qualidade.

Para iniciar a análise, o usuário escolhe um dia marciano (sol) que serve como uma referência temporal das paisagens espaciais. em seguida, seleciona o tipo de câmera e ativa o "Modo Comparar", o transformando em "Comparação(ON)". Ao marcar duas imagens, elas serão exibidas lado a lado automaticamente e podem ser manipuladas. Outra forma possível é clicar diretamente no botão "Comparar" das imagens escolhidas.

Benefícios:

As ferramentas do ISA contribuem para captura de pequenos detalhes nas imagens, permitindo a observação minuciosa de mudanças e padrões presentes entre as imagens 2D simultaneamente. Ademais, o modelo oferece uma exploração livre acessível para todos os públicos, estimulando o interesse geral por astronomia.

Impacto pretendido:

-Desenvolver uma plataforma prática para o público geral.

- Inspirar pessoas ao redor do mundo a explorar e pesquisar sobre nosso Universo, possibilitando grandes descobertas na astronomia.

Linguagens utilizadas:

-Java Script (ES6+): utilizado para tornar o site prático e dinâmico.

-HTML5: responsável pela estruturação geral do conteúdo e da interface da página web.

-CSS3: utilizado estilizar os elementos do HTML, garantindo uma interface gráfica amigável.

-JSON: formato leve para troca de dados entre as APIs da NASA e o navegador.

Criatividade:

- Integração eficiente entre HTML, CSS e JavaScript.

- Implementação de um modelo interativo.

Fatores Considerados:

- Acesso para todos os dispositivos.

- Interface simples e intuitiva.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Como iniciantes, utilizamos o ChatGPT-4 e o Gemini (2.5 Flash) para auxiliar na organização, para feedback de concordância de textos discursivos, aprimoração da estrutura do nosso código, explicação de alguns comandos e conceitos, acesso para outras APIs da NASA, acrescentar as APIs no código de forma rápida, e para tradução. Os elementos que compõem o site, as ideias e o trabalho do projeto foram construídos pela nossa equipe.

challengeDetails.title: Embiggen Your Eyes!
challengeDetails.excerpt: While your cell phone screen can display about three million pixels of information and your eye can receive more than ten million pixels, NASA images from space are even bigger! NASA’s space missions continue to push the boundaries of what is technologically possible, providing high-resolution images and videos of Earth, other planets, and space with billions or even trillions of pixels. Your challenge is to create a platform that allows users to zoom in and out on these massive image datasets, label known features, and discover new patterns. (Astrophysics Division)

node.title: Bloom team
node.excerpt:
Equipe Bloom
Somos a Bloom Team, um grupo entusiasmado em explorar a beleza e a ciência por trás da floração das plantas através dos dados.

projectDetails.name: MODIS Bloom Tracker
projectDetails.summary:
O projeto MODIS Bloom Tracker foi feito com o objetivo de facilitar o estudo/analise sobre as plantas da Caatinga do Nordeste Brasileiro. A equipe Bloom team aproveitou dos recursos do Earthdata Search (NASA) para fazer um mapa que analisa NVDI, e para conseguir informações para o mapa interativo. 
O mapa interativo mostra as plantas que irão desabrochar separado por regiões do nordeste. Ao clicar no card da planta um pop-up ira aparecer mostrando as especificações da planta de forma simples de entender. Além disso o projeto contem uma ferramenta de comparação entre a flora de diferentes estados, uma barra de pesquisa para saber de cada planta, e a opção de importar os dados de cada planta em: .csv , .pdf , .json .
projectDetails.details: Nosso projeto e um site sobre o florescimento das plantas no nordeste. O site consiste em varias seções, como por exemplo o mapa, que e onde achamos o local que queremos ver o que florescera lá. Ele veio com a intenção de ajudar o publico a entender quais plantas crescem e quais estão a crescer no nordeste brasileiro. Utilizamos nele os computadores da escola de tecnologia TECHERS, e para programar o Visual Studio Code, com a linguagem Js script, html, typescript, react, CSS e python. Pretendemos que o projeto ajude o publico a entender melhor como o florescimento de plantas funciona no nordeste brasileiro. Nosso projeto e criativo porque ele traz uma proposta nunca antes vista, com um mapa e pop-ups que ajudam a diminuicao de poluição visual na tela. Nosso time considerou os fatores clima, temperatura, quantidade de sol que a área recebe e umidade do ar. Para as pesquisas e programação do site, usamos o Canva, site oficial do IBGE (Instituto Brasileiro de Geografia e Estatística), (continuação) pinterest para imagens, Earth Data Search, Git Hub, Gemini, ChatGPT, Claude.ai, Vscode, Netlify.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
O desenvolvimento do nosso projeto para o NASA Space Apps Challenge 2025 foi otimizado pela integração estratégica de plataformas de Inteligência Artificial generativa. Essa abordagem multimídia e interativa foi fundamental para superarmos desafios técnicos complexos e garantirmos a entrega dentro do rigoroso prazo do hackathon.

Nossa equipe utilizou o seguinte ecossistema de ferramentas de IA para acelerar e aprimorar significativamente diversas etapas do trabalho:

  • Google Gemini: Empregado majoritariamente na fase crítica de backend, atuando na resolução de erros ambientais e de compatibilidade que envolviam o ambiente Python e as bibliotecas de acesso a dados da NASA. Foi essencial na formulação da solução final robusta para a autenticação e o processamento eficiente de grandes volumes de dados geoespaciais (MODIS).
  • ChatGPT: Utilizado como recurso auxiliar no refinamento de algoritmos, na estruturação da arquitetura da aplicação React e na geração de snippets de código para otimização do frontend e da lógica de apresentação dos resultados.
  • Claude.ai: Aplicado na fase de concepção e design, tanto para gerar conceitos visuais quanto para auxiliar na criação de textos e prompts criativos, garantindo que a comunicação e a estética do projeto final fossem profissionais e envolventes.

A sinergia dessas ferramentas de IA nos permitiu focar na inovação e na lógica de negócio, demonstrando a aplicação prática da Inteligência Artificial como uma ferramenta colaborativa e catalisadora de excelência técnica no contexto de um desafio de alto nível como o NASA Space Apps.

projectDetails.name: Project Brazuca - Plantando o Futuro
projectDetails.summary:
Education faces a major challenge: effectively integrating technology to engage students and develop citizens who are aware of the environmental and social impacts of human activities. While public policies and traditional methods are progressing slowly, new generations demand practical, up-to-date experiences connected to the real world.

Our solution addresses this challenge with an educational game that uses real-time NASA data to simulate agricultural scenarios in different regions of Brazil. The player chooses a crop and a state (for example, planting coffee in Rio Grande do Sul) and the system analyzes climate, terrain, and environmental events to demonstrate the viability and impacts of this choice. Wildfires, climate variations, and other real-world phenomena are automatically captured and directly affect crops in the game, connecting students to the living dynamics of the environment.

The result is an innovative tool that combines hands-on learning, gamification, and reliable scientific data to transform environmental education. In this initial phase, we're starting in Brazil, but our vision is global: to bring this interactive experience to schools and players worldwide, fostering collaboration, knowledge exchange, and planetary awareness.
projectDetails.details:
Project links:

  • Repository: https://github.com/3up-Dev/hackathon-nasa-2025
  • Published Project: https://nasa.3up.tech



1. WHAT DOES IT DO OR HOW DOES IT WORK

Plantando Futuro (“Planting the Future”) is an educational simulation game that teaches sustainable agriculture and climate awareness through interactive gameplay.
The application allows users to simulate the entire agricultural production cycle across Brazil’s 27 states using real NASA and INMET climate data.
Players select from 13 crops across 5 agricultural sectors (Agriculture, Livestock, Aquaculture, Forestry, and Horticulture), manage resources, respond to real-time environmental alerts, and earn sustainability-based rewards.

1.1 Core Functionality

  1. User Authentication and Profile Management:
    Secure login via Supabase Auth with persistent user profiles and multiple game slots per account.
  2. Crop and Location Selection:
    Interactive map of Brazil where players choose crops and states.
    Each state uses real geographic coordinates to fetch climate data.
  3. Pre-Planting Viability Analysis:
    The system calculates the compatibility between selected crop and regional conditions using NASA POWER data (temperature, rainfall, humidity, evapotranspiration).
  4. Production Cycle Simulation:
    Players advance through a 120-day virtual growing season, completing management tasks such as irrigation, pest control, and fertilization.
    The system dynamically generates events like droughts, floods, or fires using NASA and INMET data.
  5. Real-Time Climate Alerts:
    Integrations with NASA FIRMS and INMET APIs provide real-time wildfire and meteorological alerts that directly affect gameplay variables such as crop health and sustainability score.
    • Health (40%)
    • Sustainability (30%)
    • Water Efficiency (30%)
      Players earn medals (Gold, Silver, Bronze) and can compare results in a dashboard.
  6. Progressive Web App (PWA):
    Fully installable on mobile and desktop, with offline functionality and caching for low-connectivity environments.

2. WHAT BENEFITS DOES IT HAVE

  1. Educational Value:
    Simplifies complex climate and agricultural concepts through interactive simulation.
    Players learn how environmental decisions influence sustainability and productivity.
  2. Real Data Integration:
    Uses verified NASA and INMET data, ensuring scientific accuracy and trustworthiness.
  3. Engagement through Gamification:
    Combines education with entertainment, enhancing user retention and motivation.
  4. Accessibility and Inclusion:
    PWA support enables access on any device, even in low-bandwidth areas.
    Interface available in Portuguese and English for broader reach.
  5. Environmental Awareness:
    Encourages critical thinking about sustainability and responsible resource management.

3. WHAT IS THE INTENDED IMPACT OF THE PROJECT

  1. Educational Transformation:
    Converts environmental science into an engaging, visual, and practical learning experience.
    Players can understand the link between climate data and agricultural outcomes in real time.
  2. Critical Thinking and Responsibility:
    Demonstrates how local decisions affect global sustainability.
    Encourages reflection on water usage, emissions, and biodiversity.
  3. Regional and Social Inclusion:
    Promotes awareness of Brazil’s diverse climates and ecosystems.
    Provides accessible educational material for schools, NGOs, and rural communities.
  4. Institutional Adoption:
    Designed to serve as an educational resource for schools and environmental programs.
    Can be used in classrooms or workshops to complement sustainability education.
  5. Long-Term Awareness:
    Aims to build lasting environmental responsibility and inspire young generations to consider sustainability in real-world decision-making.

4. WHAT TOOLS, CODING LANGUAGES, HARDWARE, OR SOFTWARE WERE USED

4.1 Frontend Stack

  • React 18.3.1: Component-based UI framework.
  • TypeScript: Static typing and compile-time validation.
  • Vite: High-speed development build tool.
  • Tailwind CSS: Responsive utility-first styling.
  • shadcn/ui: Accessible UI components (based on Radix UI).
  • Zustand 5.0.8: Lightweight global state management.
  • React Router DOM 6.30.1: Protected route management.
  • React Hook Form + Zod: Validation and schema enforcement.
  • Recharts 2.15.4: Data visualization.
  • date-fns 3.6.0: Date and time handling.

4.2 Backend Infrastructure

  • Supabase: Backend-as-a-Service (PostgreSQL, Auth, and Edge Functions).
  • Supabase Auth: Secure authentication with JWT.
  • Row-Level Security: User-level data isolation.
  • Deno Edge Functions: Serverless integrations for NASA and INMET APIs.

4.3 External APIs

  1. NASA POWER API (Climate Data)
    Consumption File: supabase/functions/get-nasa-climate-data/index.ts
    NASA Endpoint: https://power.larc.nasa.gov/api/temporal/daily/point

Location in Code: Key lines 34-196

  1. NASA FIRMS API (Fire Detection)
    Consumption File: supabase/functions/get-brazil-climate-alerts/index.ts
    NASA Endpoint: https://firms.modaps.eosdis.nasa.gov/api/area/csv/{MAP_KEY}/VIIRS_NOAA20_NRT/...

Returned Data:

  • Fire hotspots (latitude, longitude, confidence)
  • Fire risk alerts by state

Location in Code: Key lines 91-159 (fire data fetching)

4.4 Deployment and Hardware

  • Hosting: Lovable Cloud (auto-deploy via Git push).
  • Database: Supabase PostgreSQL.
  • Devices: Any modern web browser (desktop or mobile).
  • Connectivity: Internet for real-time data; offline support via PWA caching.

5. HOW IS THE PROJECT CREATIVE

  1. Real Satellite Data Integration:
    First educational game to combine NASA POWER (climate) and FIRMS (fire) data for interactive sustainability simulation.
  2. Dynamic Environmental Gameplay:
    Real-time data directly influences the player’s outcomes — fires, droughts, and rainfall events generate immediate feedback and learning moments.
  3. Gamified Learning Framework:
    Transforms scientific knowledge into an engaging experience through challenges, scoring systems, and medal rewards.
  4. Cross-Disciplinary Approach:
    Combines data science, game design, and environmental education into a unified, accessible tool.
  5. Visual and UX Creativity:
    Uses pixel-art style and simple interactive dashboards to make complex climate data intuitive for all audiences.

6. WHAT FACTORS DID THE TEAM CONSIDER

  1. Pedagogical Design:
    Educational balance between scientific accuracy and accessible learning for ages 10 and up.
    Concepts simplified without losing data integrity.
  2. Accessibility and Inclusivity:
    Compliance with WCAG accessibility standards and full keyboard navigation.
    Color contrast verified for color blindness.
  3. Localization:
    Native Portuguese interface with English translation.
    Temperature and precipitation units adapted per locale.
  4. Scalability:
    Modular architecture allows adding new crops or data sources easily.
    APIs abstracted via edge functions for rapid expansion.
  5. Resilience and Offline Access:
    Built as a Progressive Web App to support unstable internet connections common in rural areas.
  6. Cultural Context:
    All examples, crops, and terminology based on Brazilian agriculture, ensuring local relevance while maintaining global applicability.

Conclusion

Plantando Futuro is an innovative educational platform that merges space technology, climate data, and game design to raise awareness about sustainable agriculture.
By transforming real NASA and INMET data into interactive learning, it enables players to understand — in an intuitive, hands-on way — how environmental conditions shape the world we live in.


Project links:

  • Repository: https://github.com/3up-Dev/hackathon-nasa-2025
  • Published Project: https://nasa.3up.tech
  • YouTube Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLOzDeXtllw

projectDetails.name: Exoplanet Classification Tool
projectDetails.summary:
We developed the Exoplanet Classification Tool, an interactive web application that leverages a machine learning model to classify exoplanet candidates from NASA's Kepler mission data. The primary challenge in the field is efficiently vetting the vast number of potential signals (KOIs) to identify the most promising candidates.

Our tool addresses this by allowing researchers to upload their data and receive an instant classification of each object as 'CONFIRMED' or 'FALSE POSITIVE', based on a high-accuracy (99%) Random Forest model. Crucially, the tool goes beyond simple prediction. For each classification, it provides a detailed technical justification using SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), showing exactly which astronomical parameters most influenced the decision.

This is important because by providing fast, accurate, and interpretable classifications, the tool serves as a powerful decision-support resource, helping astronomers prioritize candidates, building trust in the AI's results, and accelerating the pace of exoplanet discovery.
projectDetails.details:
The Exoplanet Classification Tool is a web application designed to automate and accelerate the vetting of potential exoplanets. The workflow is simple and direct:

  1. Data Upload: An astronomer or researcher submits a CSV file containing data for exoplanet candidates (Kepler Objects of Interest - KOIs).
    • Feature Selection: From the raw data, the system selects only the 52 features that proved most predictive in the original data analysis. Columns with a high percentage of missing values, identifiers (kepid), redundant data, and parameters not directly related to the transit's physical properties were systematically removed.
    • Missing Data Handling: If any of the 52 essential features are missing from the user's file (or contain empty cells), the system automatically fills them with pre-calculated average values from the original training dataset, ensuring consistency.
  2. AI Classification: The clean data is then fed into a high-accuracy (99%) Random Forest machine learning model, which classifies each candidate as either "CONFIRMED" or "FALSE POSITIVE".
  3. Visualization and Analysis: The results are presented in an interactive interface featuring a dashboard, tables, and most importantly, an Individual Analysis section. Here, a researcher can select any candidate and view a graph (SHAP Force Plot) and a detailed technical justification that explains exactly which factors led to that specific classification.

The primary benefit of the tool is efficiency and trust. The process of vetting exoplanet candidates is time-consuming and complex. Our tool drastically reduces the time required for an initial screening, allowing researchers to focus on the most promising candidates.

The intended impact is to accelerate the pace of exoplanet discovery. By providing not only a fast and accurate classification but also a transparent explanation of the "why" behind each AI decision, the tool serves as a powerful decision-support resource. It enables astronomers to prioritize targets for follow-up observations with more powerful telescopes, optimizing resources and speeding up the confirmation of new worlds.

The project was developed entirely with open-source software, requiring no specific hardware.

  • Programming Language: Python
  • Backend (Artificial Intelligence): Scikit-learn (for the Random Forest model), Pandas (for data manipulation), and Joblib (for model serialization).
  • Frontend (Web Interface): Streamlit.
  • Data Visualization: Plotly and Matplotlib.
  • AI Explainability: SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), a state-of-the-art library for interpreting machine learning model predictions.

The project's creativity lies in the integration of three complex components into a single, simple, and accessible tool. We combined:

  1. A high-performance machine learning model.
  2. An AI explainability framework (SHAP) that "translates" the model's decisions.
  3. An interactive and intuitive user interface.

Instead of being a "black box," the tool makes the AI's decision-making transparent and understandable to domain experts (astrophysicists), who can validate whether the model's reasoning is scientifically sound. This bridge between advanced data science and practical application in astronomical research is the project's main creative distinction.

The key factors considered were:

  • Scientific Rigor: Ensuring the AI model was trained and validated with a robust methodology (cross-validation) to achieve high accuracy and reliability.
  • User Experience (UX): Designing a clean, minimalist, and intuitive interface that would allow a researcher to use the tool without needing expertise in programming or machine learning.
  • Interpretability: The most important factor. From the outset, the project was designed with the idea that the explanation behind a classification was as crucial as the classification itself. We wanted the tool to build trust, not just provide answers.

Code and data: Google Gemini was used as an AI assistant to support the prototyping of the project's web interface. Its role was limited to helping outline the initial Streamlit layout and generate sample CSS elements.

projectDetails.name: Code and cheese
projectDetails.summary:
Our project addresses NASA's "Will it rain at my parade?" challenge by developing an intelligent system capable of calculating the probability of adverse weather conditions months in advance, using 20 years of historical data from the NASA POWER API.

Unlike traditional weather forecasts, which have a limited range (1–2 weeks), our solution is based on long-term observational data, allowing us to identify historical patterns and climate trends for any specific location and date on Earth.

The system applies a multi-criteria statistical methodology—temperature, precipitation, wind, and humidity—to assess the weather suitability of outdoor events such as weddings, festivals, harvests, or sporting activities. From this analysis, it generates a historical probability (0–100%) of event success and suggests more favorable alternative dates within a range of ±30 days.
projectDetails.details:
This project addresses NASA's "Will it rain on my parade?" challenge by building an application that allows users to make personalized queries to determine the probability of adverse weather conditions for a specific location and time.

The Problem: Planning outdoor events - vacations, hikes, fishing trips, weddings, festivals - without knowing the chances of bad weather conditions ("too hot", "too cold", "too windy", "too wet" or "too uncomfortable").

Our Solution: A system that analyzes 20 years of NASA historical data to calculate accurate weather condition probabilities, allowing users to be better prepared and make informed decisions months in advance.

Important: This is not a weather forecast! These are probabilities based on historical data, not predictive models. This allows planning months in advance, something traditional forecasts (1-2 weeks) cannot offer.


NASA Earth Observation Data

Primary Source: NASA POWER API

We use the NASA POWER API (Prediction Of Worldwide Energy Resources), which provides global meteorological data on temperature, precipitation, wind, and humidity collected over several decades
The system analyzes 20 years of historical data (2005-2025) for each specific location and date, building a robust statistical compendium that enables pattern identification and reliable probability calculations.

Key Features

  • Location Selection: Interactive map with global coverage and precise coordinates- Personalized Query: Date and time selection with advance planning (months ahead)
  • Event Profiles: Predefined templates (picnic, wedding, sports, festival, photography) or custom criteria via LLM assistant- Probability Analysis: Visual gauge 0-100% based on NASA historical data
  • Alternative Dates: Comparative heatmap (±30 days) highlighting the best option
  • Complete Export: CSV/JSON download with metadata and sharing

How We Process the Data

Processing Pipeline

Our system follows a structured workflow to ensure accurate and reliable analyses:


Processing Steps:
  1. User Input: Location (latitude/longitude) + Specific date
  2. NASA POWER API Query: Fetch historical data (2005-2025)
  3. Data Aggregation: Organize by calendar date
  4. Criteria Application: Compare with event criteria (temperature, rain, wind, humidity)
  5. Probability Calculation: Historical analysis + recent trends
  6. Trend Analysis: Identify patterns (positive/negative/stable)
  7. Alternative Generation: Suggest nearby dates (±30 days)
  8. Results Formatting: Present probability (0-100%) + classification
  9. User Display: Clear and intuitive interface

Data Analysis in Detail

Temperature Variation Over 20 Years

This visualization shows how temperature varies on the chosen date over the last 20 years. The dashed lines indicate:

  • Green: Ideal minimum temperature for the event
  • Red: Safe maximum temperature

Usefulness: Identifies temperature patterns and extremes, helping assess if the date is consistently suitable.


Precipitation Pattern


Year-by-year analysis of precipitation on the chosen date:

  • Green Bars: Years with acceptable precipitation (≤1mm)
  • Red Bars: Years with excessive rain (>1mm)

Insights: Assesses rain risk and identifies historically problematic years.


Multi-Parameter Dashboard


Comprehensive view of all climate parameters:

  • Temperature: Minimum and maximum range
  • Precipitation: Intensity over the years
  • Wind Speed: Trends and safety limits
  • Relative Humidity: Comfort and atmospheric conditions

Advantage: Enables holistic analysis of all climate factors simultaneously.

Criteria Evaluation

Each year is evaluated based on all defined criteria:

  • Green: Year that met all criteria
  • Red: Year that failed one or more criteria

Calculation: Probability = (Ideal Years / Total Years) × 100%
Application: Provides the historical probability of success for your event.


Alternative Dates Heat Map

Compares the chosen date's probability with nearby dates (±15 days):

  • Blue Border: User-selected date
  • Golden Border: Best alternative identified

Benefit: Suggests better dates if the chosen one is not ideal.

Summary Infographic

Complete dashboard with all key metrics:

  • Main Probability: Large, color-coded percentage
  • Average Temperature: Mean of maximum temperatures
  • Rain Distribution: Proportion of dry vs. rainy days
  • Wind Analysis: Safe years vs. strong winds
  • Historical Timeline: Year-by-year visualization (2005-2025)

Usefulness: Complete executive view for quick decision-making.

How It Works in Practice

Scenario: Planning a barbecue in Uberlândia on August 15, 2026, at 2:00 PM


Select the location on the map

Click on Uberlândia or enter coordinates manually!

Choose the event date and time

Set August 15, 2026, at 2:00 PM!

Select the event profile

Choose "Barbecue" or customize weather criteria!

View analysis results

Check the probability and detailed historical data!

Analyze climate trends

Compare data from the last two decades!

Explore alternative dates

In this example, August 15 showed 100% ideal probability. To demonstrate the alternative feature, we also tested October 24, 2025 (35% probability), which shows suggested nearby dates with better conditions.

Export data for analysis

Download results in CSV or JSON

Scientific Methodology

Data Used

Primary Source: [NASA POWER API](https://power.larc.nasa.gov/)

  • System: Prediction Of Worldwide Energy Resources
  • Analysis Period: 2005-2025 (two decades)
  • Coverage: Global (any point on Earth)
  • Temporal Resolution: Daily or hourly
  • Spatial Resolution: 0.5° × 0.5° (~55km at equator)

Measured Parameters (Adverse Condition Detection):

  • T2M_MAX / T2M_MIN | T2M - Temperature at 2m (°C)
    • Detects: "too hot" or "too cold" conditions
    • Detects: "too wet" conditions (rain)
    • Detects: "too windy" conditions
    • Detects: "too uncomfortable" conditions

Benefits and Impact

For Event Organizers
  • Reduction of cancellations, postponements, and losses
  • Better contingency planning
  • Greater participant satisfaction and safety
For Participants
  • Confidence in event execution
  • Adequate preparation (clothing, equipment)
  • Greater comfort and safety in outdoor activities
For the Community
  • Democratization of access to quality scientific data
  • Evidence-based decisions
  • Awareness of local climate change

Additional Resources

  • NASA POWER API Documentation
  • Source Code on GitHub
  • Application Demo

Conclusion

Answering the Challenge: "Will It Rain on My Parade?"

Yes, now you can know!
This system addresses NASA's challenge by creating an accessible bridge between complex Earth observation scientific data and practical everyday decisions.


Our Contribution:

  • Personalized interface that anyone can use
  • Accurate probabilities** based on NASA historical data (2005-2025)
  • Clear visualizations that make complex data understandable
  • Advance planning that traditional forecasts cannot offer

NASA science serving people. Earth observation data for everyone.

NASA Space Apps Challenge 2025

Challenge: Will it rain on my parade?

Team: Code and Cheese

Technologies Used:

  • Data Source: NASA POWER API
  • Frontend: React, TypeScript, React Router v7
  • Backend: Node.js, Bun
  • Data Analysis: Python, Jupyter Notebook, Machine Learning
  • UI/UX: Tailwind CSS v4, shadcn/ui, Radix UI
  • Maps: Leaflet, React Leaflet
  • Deployment: Vercel, Coolify
  • AI Assistants: Claude Code, Gemini CLI, GitHub Copilot
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Our team utilized AI tools as productivity assistants throughout the development process:

AI Tools Used
  • Claude Code: Code generation, debugging, refactoring, and architecture planning for React components, TypeScript definitions, and NASA POWER API integration.
  • GitHub Copilot: Real-time code suggestions, autocompletion, and boilerplate generation for frontend components and utilities.
  • Gemini CLI: Command-line assistance, script generation, and data processing workflows.
Applications
  • Code Development: Component structure, TypeScript interfaces, data processing logic, and UI implementation
  • Documentation: Technical documentation, README files, and project descriptions
  • Data Analysis: Guidance on statistical methods and Python code for Jupyter Notebooks
Originality Statement

All AI-generated content was reviewed, tested, and modified by our team. AI tools served as assistive technologies only. Original team contributions include:

  • Project concept and problem-solving approach- UI/UX design and user experience flow
  • Data processing methodology and probability algorithms
  • Scientific methodology and analytical frameworks
  • Integration architecture

No AI-generated images, videos, or audio were used. All visualizations were created using legitimate data visualization libraries processing real NASA POWER API data (2005-2025).

projectDetails.name: Project Cosbit
projectDetails.summary: What I developed was software that uses a Space Biological Agent and a Data Analyst Agent to analyze and understand documents from space biology experiments and provide practical and objective insights and valuable information from the documents, thus transforming raw data into intelligent data ready for human decision-making and interpretation.This way, the productivity and gains in the work of researchers, scientists, enthusiasts, etc., increase by trying to assimilate and understand what the data is saying.
projectDetails.details:
What benefits does BioExpace offer?

It can extract any data structure you want from the document and provide you with intelligent information based on the context given to it.

This summarizes a lot of manual work and saves human time and energy from reading and understanding numerous documents.

This way, you can get straight to the point. The data is about Space Biology,

which is essential for understanding how life transforms and adapts in space.

BioExpace offers a bridge between knowledge and data generated by NASA professionals

and modern intelligence capable of transforming how you perceive data.

What is the intended impact of the project?

To gather raw data and be able to display valuable information to the end human user, it takes

all the sections (for example, Introduction, Results, Conclusion) of all documents,

analyzes everything, and generates in a practical and useful way information that may be valuable to you,

information that you might spend hours analyzing to find what you're looking for.

Which tools, programming languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

  • Languages: Python, HTML, CSS, and JavaScript
  • Frameworks:
  • Flask (good for microservices),
  • Ollama (for integrating LLMs on my local machine),
  • TikToken (for token control by chunk)
  • Database: PostgreSQL (used to store data collection, agent pipelines, and the structure of the final result)
  • Final Data Format: JSON (JSONB in PostgreSQL)
  • Hardware: Local server with only CPU, 16GB of RAM, Ubuntu operating system, no cloud dependency.

How is your project creative?

It uses text comprehension models (NLP) to analyze thousands of tokens in documents, assimilate everything, organize everything

and generate valuable information. It allows quick access to information and the possible generation

of new biological hypotheses thanks to what the Agents provide to us humans.

Furthermore, the idea of collaborative cognitive agents (one reads, another interprets) and the fusion of spatial

biology and intelligent data (thanks to AI), the notion of augmented science, and the way

data is transformed into intelligent information for this branch of science.

There are two agents working on multiple scientific documents, reviewing and generating information

What factors did your team consider?

The fact is that today, we humans are always needing more convenience, more objectivity, more speed.

Tools like this, which save 85% of your work time, make you more productive, not to mention that, of course,

the better the LLM model used, the smarter and better your final result will be. We solved that problem of scattered and possibly meaningless data,

bringing relevance in a simple and objective way, whatever your purpose may be. We solve and facilitate your exploration of the data
projectDetails.aiReferences:
In addition to using Qween and LLama for data analysis, I used ChatGPT during development for the frontend; it helped me with corrections in JavaScript, some HTML definitions, and quick styling.

I defined how I wanted the design to look, and he styled it in CSS. I started developing some frontend-backend integrations and requested corrections in the JavaScript in cases of errors.

challengeDetails.title: Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine
challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! NASA has been performing biology experiments in space for decades, generating a tremendous amount of information that will need to be considered as humans prepare to revisit the Moon and explore Mars. Although this knowledge is publicly available, it can be difficult for potential users to find information that pertains to their specific interests. Your challenge is to build a dynamic dashboard that leverages artificial intelligence (AI), knowledge graphs, and/or other tools to summarize a set of NASA bioscience publications and enables users to explore the impacts and results of the experiments these publications describe. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. projectDetails.name: CosmoEX: Simplificando o acesso à pesquisa espacial com IA
projectDetails.summary:
Somos a equipe CosmoEX: Exploradores do Cosmos, e nossa missão é democratizar o acesso ao conhecimento científico, tornando as descobertas da NASA acessíveis a todos. Desenvolvemos uma inteligência artificial conversacional que responde perguntas em linguagem natural com base em artigos, dados e publicações oficiais da NASA.

O CosmoEX funciona como um assistente semelhante ao ChatGPT, mas voltado exclusivamente para conteúdos científicos e espaciais. Ao digitar perguntas como “O que a NASA descobriu sobre buracos negros?”, o usuário recebe respostas contextualizadas e baseadas em fontes verificadas, além do link para o arquivo completo, aproximando a ciência da vida cotidiana.

Nosso sistema foi construído com
projectDetails.details:
Introdução

Em um mundo movido pela informação, o conhecimento científico é uma das ferramentas mais poderosas para o avanço da humanidade. No entanto, o acesso a esse conhecimento ainda é desigual. Diariamente, estudantes, pesquisadores independentes e pequenos cientistas enfrentam grandes barreiras para encontrar e compreender artigos científicos relevantes, um processo demorado, técnico e, muitas vezes, desmotivador.

O CosmoEX nasce com o propósito de democratizar o acesso às pesquisas, transformando a busca por conhecimento em uma experiência simples, intuitiva e acessível.

O problema

A pesquisa científica, apesar de essencial, ainda é vista como inacessível para a maioria. Universitários e pequenos pesquisadores frequentemente gastam horas ou até dias tentando filtrar centenas de artigos em busca de poucos que realmente contribuem para suas hipóteses.

Essa dificuldade em encontrar materiais relevantes não é apenas um desafio técnico, mas também um obstáculo emocional e social. Muitos acabam desistindo de seus projetos por frustração ou por falta de recursos. O resultado é uma perda significativa de potencial intelectual e inovação, especialmente em países em desenvolvimento, onde o acesso à informação científica de qualidade ainda é limitado.

A lacuna

Apesar da imensa disponibilidade de dados e artigos científicos abertos, a ponte entre a informação e quem precisa dela ainda é frágil. As plataformas de pesquisa existentes são complexas e pouco intuitivas.

Em outras palavras, há um abismo entre a curiosidade e o conhecimento, e é justamente essa lacuna que o CosmoEX se propõe a preencher.

Nossa solução

O CosmoEX é uma inteligência artificial conversacional projetada para simplificar e acelerar o acesso a pesquisas científicas, utilizando os dados e artigos disponibilizados pela NASA. Por meio de uma interface semelhante a um chat, o usuário pode fazer perguntas em linguagem natural, por exemplo:

“O que a NASA descobriu sobre buracos negros?”

A IA processa a consulta, busca informações em seu banco de dados, e responde de forma contextualizada e confiável, além do link para o artigo completo.

Com o CosmoEX, estudantes e pesquisadores podem conversar diretamente com o conhecimento, economizando tempo e abrindo novas portas para descobertas.

Como funciona

Detalhes da implementação

Impacto

O CosmoEX tem o potencial de revolucionar o acesso à pesquisa científica, reduzindo drasticamente o tempo de busca por informações relevantes. Ele democratiza o conhecimento, permitindo que estudantes, curiosos e cientistas independentes explorem dados da NASA de forma simples, eliminando barreiras técnicas e linguísticas.

Com o uso do CosmoEX, mais pessoas poderão participar ativamente da construção do conhecimento científico, estimulando o pensamento crítico, a inovação e o interesse pela ciência. Em longo prazo, isso significa uma sociedade mais informada, colaborativa e preparada para resolver desafios globais, exatamente como a NASA sempre inspirou.

Conclusão

O CosmoEX representa o encontro entre tecnologia, curiosidade e propósito.
Mais do que uma ferramenta, é um movimento em prol da democratização da ciência. Ao transformar dados complexos em conhecimento acessível, nosso projeto busca inspirar novas gerações de exploradores, não apenas do espaço, mas do saber.

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: DataLab Exoplanet Hunter: IA na Busca por Mundos Distantes
projectDetails.summary:
No desafio global da NASA A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI, a equipe DataLab desenvolveu uma solução baseada em inteligência artificial para acelerar a identificação de possíveis exoplanetas em meio a grandes volumes de dados astrofísicos. Utilizamos o modelo LightGBM, uma técnica avançada de aprendizado de máquina em árvore de decisão, conhecida por sua velocidade e alta performance em tarefas de classificação.

Nosso sistema foi treinado para analisar curvas de luz — registros que mostram variações no brilho de estrelas ao longo do tempo — e detectar padrões sutis que podem indicar o trânsito de planetas em frente a essas estrelas. Para isso, aplicamos técnicas de engenharia de atributos, tratamento de ruídos nos dados, validação cruzada e otimização de hiperparâmetros, construindo um pipeline robusto, eficiente e reprodutível.

Essa abordagem não só permite automatizar e escalar a triagem de candidatos a exoplanetas, como também libera tempo dos astrônomos para investigações mais aprofundadas. O projeto reforça o potencial da inteligência artificial como aliada na exploração espacial e no avanço do conhecimento humano sobre mundos além do nosso sistema solar.
projectDetails.details:
Como funciona ou o que faz?

Projeto desenvolve na detecção de exoplanetas obtidos através de dados de missões do K2,

foi feito para atender pesquisadores e profissionais na área como meio de facilitador de analise de detecção e confirmação de planetas como exoplanetas,

através parte interativa do front end é possível subir um data set, no qual o projeto pre processa internamente para verificação das variáveis para identificar se as colunas (variáveis) seja categoricas, numerica (float, int, etc)...

por meio de hiperparametros pre definidas no modelo...

--------------------

Quais São os beneficios?
Para a identificação de exoplanetas, são necessários dados astrofísicos, com a dificuldade de catalogar planetas como explanetas é necassário a utilização de modelos preditivos e inteligência artifical para auxiliar e acelerar a dectacção.


-----------------------

Qual é o impacto pretendido do projeto

poupando tempo para calculos manuais e liberando o profissional ou o pesquisador para outras atividades que requerem atenção...

-------------------

foi utilizado as ferramentas visual studio, google colab, na linguagem de programação Python, a utilização de inteligência artificial como o Gemini, ChatGPT, perplexity, Copilit.

Crie uma que faça sentido para gente.

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Asan e o diário espacial
projectDetails.summary:
O projeto desenvolveu um livro digital interativo voltado para estudantes do Ensino Fundamental, com o objetivo de tornar acessíveis e envolventes os conceitos sobre o clima espacial e sua relação com a vida na Terra. Embora o Sol esteja a 93 milhões de milhas de distância, sua atividade pode impactar diretamente nosso cotidiano, interferindo em tecnologias, comunicações e até na agricultura.
Na história, Asan, um menino curioso apaixonado pelo espaço, e Estela, sua amiga criativa, encontram o diário perdido de um astronauta. A partir dessas páginas misteriosas, os dois embarcam em uma aventura de descobertas sobre o Sol, o universo e a importância das pesquisas realizadas pela NASA para o bem da humanidade.
De forma lúdica e poética, o livro estimula a curiosidade científica, o pensamento criativo e o cuidado com o conhecimento compartilhado, convidando as crianças a explorar, imaginar e registrar suas próprias ideias — como verdadeiros exploradores do espaço.
projectDetails.details: Este projeto oferece uma ferramenta educacional digital e interativa, projetada para o público do Ensino Fundamental. A obra elucida alguns conceitos sobre o clima espacial. O benefícios que pretendemos alcançar é facilitar o estudo e entendimento sobre o clima solar, para que diversos públicos consigam ter acesso a um fácil entendimento sobre o assunto e também claro, despertar a vontade de saber mais sobre o assunto. A ferramenta destaca a relevância prática do assunto, mostrando como a atividade solar impacta diretamente o cotidiano, desde o funcionamento de satélites até a produção de alimentos. Utilizamos a plataforma Canva para o desenvolvimento do material interativo digital. Pegamos como base para começar a trabalhar o projeto de extensão "Diário de ideias" da professora Luciana Soares Muniz no qual participamos
