node.title: Earth Trailblazers
node.excerpt: A couple vibing with coding, design, and data analysis, on a mission to explore and innovate by transforming complex data into impactful solutions :)

projectDetails.name: METEORIS by Earth Trailblazers
projectDetails.summary:
We, the Earth Trailblazers team, developed METEORIS, an innovative web application designed to be a true lifesaver for tourists planning trips anywhere in Brazil. Through an intuitive and interactive interface, users can search for a destination city or select it directly on an interactive map. By specifying the month and year of their planned trip, they receive detailed climate predictions, including average minimum and maximum temperatures, rainfall in millimeters, and the probability of rain.

Beyond forecasts, METEORIS displays insightful historical weather graphs generated from NASA Earth observation data spanning 2007–2025, enhancing the model’s reliability. The app also provides personalized travel tips based on predicted conditions, helping users plan better experiences.

This solution addresses NASA’s challenge “Will it rain on my parade?” by going beyond short-term forecasts — offering long-term, data-driven planning for travelers, months or even years in advance. METEORIS stands out for its relevance: while many apps predict short-term weather, few empower users to anticipate future climate tendencies and avoid unpleasant surprises during their dream trips.
projectDetails.details:
Overview
METEORIS is an AI-powered web application that predicts future climate conditions for any location in Brazil, based on the month and year selected by the user. The system provides max., min. and mean temperature and precipitation, interactive climate plots, and travel recommendations tailored to the expected weather. It helps tourists plan their trips in advance, while also offering a data-driven dashboard for climate analysis enthusiasts.

Dataset
The dataset was built from NASA Earth observation data provided by the Global Earth Science Data and Information Service (GES DISC). Data were collected from three sources:

  • M2TMNXSLV (surface and atmospheric variables),
  • M2TMNXRAD (radiation data), and
  • M2TMNXFLX (precipitation and flux data).

We used the EarthAccess API to authenticate and download data between 2007 and 2025, filtered specifically for Brazil’s geographic boundaries (latitude −33° to 5°, longitude −74° to −35°).
The dataset includes the following variables:

  • T2M – Air temperature 2 meters above the surface
  • QV2M – Specific humidity
  • PS – Surface pressure
  • SWGDN – Solar radiation at ground level
  • PRECTOT – Total surface precipitation

All data were consolidated into monthly averages and stored in Parquet and CSV formats for high performance and compatibility.

Machine Learning Model
We trained a LightGBM MultiOutputRegressor using Python, Pandas, NumPy, and Scikit-learn to simultaneously predict temperature and precipitation.
Before training, the data underwent:

  • Cleaning and removal of unnecessary columns;
  • Conversion of temperature (Kelvin → Celsius) and humidity (fraction → percentage);
  • Geographic filtering to ensure only Brazilian data;
  • Creation of derived features such as month, year, and temperature range.

After splitting the dataset (80% training, 20% testing) and normalizing it with StandardScaler, the model achieved an R² score of 0.92, a MAE of 0.17, and a MSE of 0.10, showing excellent predictive performance.
The model and scaler were exported using Joblib for fast loading via the backend.

Visualization and Recommendations
Using Matplotlib and Seaborn, METEORIS generates time-series plots showing trends in temperature, rainfall, and humidity across 18 years. These insights help identify ideal travel periods or regions with favorable weather.
Additionally, the application provides automatic travel tips based on forecast results, helping users discover ideal attractions under predicted conditions.

Technology Stack

  • Python (Data processing, ML, and API with FastAPI)
  • LightGBM, Scikit-learn, Pandas, NumPy
  • Matplotlib, Seaborn for visualization
  • React (frontend)
  • C# (backend)

Impact and Creativity
METEORIS transforms NASA’s open climate data into actionable insights, bridging environmental science and tourism. It stands out for combining predictive modeling, visualization, and travel intelligence in one interface — a creative approach that helps travelers, researchers, and educators understand how Earth’s climate behaves across time and space.

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project EcoLife
projectDetails.details:
In this project, our goal is to implement measures to improve the quality of life in urban centers based on the city of Uberlândia.

            Based on data provided by NASA, we confirmed that the issues we identified are real and supported by evidence.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/leaf-area-index-and-fraction-absorbed-photosynthetically

            With the leaf area index map, it is possible to see the lack of vegetation in urban centers.

1 Agroforestry

1.1  Objective

            The proposal to implement urban agroforestry systems is grounded in two main factors: lack of green areas and lack of access to quality food for low-income people.

            The implementation of community agroforestry systems in cities has several benefits, such as the availability of organic food in low-income communities, improved local air quality, environmental education, mitigating global warming through increased O₂ production, and flood prevention through increased drainage areas.

            The main purpose of creating agroforestry systems is to make food available to the community, as it is clear that the high cost of organic food means that this segment of the population cannot access it.

1.2 Implementation

            There are several difficulties involved in implementing agroforestry systems, the main one being the choice of locations to be used. The use of satellite data was considered for organizing the possible areas to be used. The main barrier in choosing these locations is private property.

            Government action is required to allocate suitable land and provide compensation to property owners.

            Agroforestry systems seek to operate with the support of NGOs and local residents for their maintenance. Through them, we seek to increase people's contact with agricultural production, thereby increasing the population's environmental education.

2 Parks/green areas

2.1  Objective

            There is a great need for green areas and parks around the city, and the lack of these areas is seen in many cities around the world. IAddressing this issue requires significant government commitment.

            Even though there are some parks in the city, there is a lack of access to them due to transportation difficulties nd their remote locations. For better use by the population, it is necessary to improve the city's transportation systems to make it easier for people to enjoy them.

2.2  Implementation

            In order to implement parks and green areas throughout the city, it is necessary to plan which areas will be suitable for their construction. Satellite images are useful for mapping these areas.

            The main problem for their implementation is the need for high investment by the government, due to their high cost and the fact that the project requires a great deal of effort by local organizations.

3  Benefits of implementing agroforests and green areas

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cams-global-greenhouse-gas-forecasts

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cams-global-inversion-optimised-greenhouse-gas-fluxes-and


            With these maps and the data provided by Copernicus, the flow of greenhouse gases was observed. This showed that topics 1 and 2 act directly against the production of greenhouse gases.

            The creation of green areas and agroforestry in urban areas, which are one of the main emitters of greenhouse gases, is extremely important for improving the local quality of life.

            These initiatives directly enhance the local population’s quality of life by improving air quality, reducing greenhouse gases through CO₂ absorption, increase humidity and reduce local temperatures, prevent flooding due to improved urban drainage, provide access to quality food, environmental education, well-being, and leisure.

4 Waste generated by the population

4.1  Objective

            Urban waste is becoming an increasingly serious problem due to improper disposal and insufficient recycling. These problems are evident in the city of Uberlândia and extend throughout the world. As a primary measure, we have decided that it is necessary to create a culture of recycling in our city through government programs.

4.2  Implementation    

            To create a culture of recycling in our city, we believe that a sense of reward for this action is necessary. With the high taxes charged to citizens, we thought of creating a system of credits for public cleaning fees and property taxes (IPTU).

            We decided that by taking public measures to encourage citizens to recycle, we will have several benefits, such as the proper management of waste generated and the reduction of waste in public spaces.

            In addition to citizens, large-scale recycling in factories is also necessary, so we also thought of a tax credit for part of the taxes that would be collected by the government.

5 Electricity 

5.1 Objective   

            The implementation of renewable energy sources has a major impact on cities.The most prominent one is photovoltaic solar energy, as it can be used to generate energy in many homes, saving citizens money on their energy bills. It can also be applied in virtually any building, such as businesses, factories, and others. In addition to solar energy, it is possible to make better use of biogas in landfills and expand to other biomass sources that transform the environmental liability of waste and organic residues into revenue and clean energy.

5.2 Implementation

            For the mass implementation of solar energy by citizens, it needs to be more accessible and less expensive for them. Currently, the main problem for the acquisition of solar energy is the high initial cost. To reduce it, there needs to be a realignment and reduction of taxes levied on such products.

            Better use of biogas in landfills eliminates methane, one of the polluting gases that causes the greenhouse effect, thereby reducing pollution generated in the city and improving energy production.

projectDetails.name: OrC (Orbital Clean)
projectDetails.summary: We developed OrC (Orbital Clean), a substation focused on transforming space debris in metallic wires which will be sold down on Earth for multiple purposes. This project contemplates the challenge of commercializing the Low Earth Orbit (LEO), presenting a viable destination for the metals filling the space in the first few thousand meters outside of the Earth. With OrC, we will guarantee the possibility of space navigation and exploration in the future, given the increasing number of space debris should prevent missions from being launched in the next few decades. Ultimately, OrC aims to reuse and commercialize what used to be considered space trash.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do or how does it work? 

OrC is responsible for capturing debris collected through a hatch in one of the bases of the cylindric structure, performing a wire drawing process on the inside in order to transform these metals into wires and storing them in boxes that will eventually be ejected back to Earth with the help of an attached parachute.

What benefits does it have? 

  • First, we aim to reduce the number of space debris around the Low Earth Orbit in order to avoid future trouble in regards to humanities’ space development. 
  • Second, our focus is on giving purpose and market value to the debris through their refinement and transformation into wires.

What is the intended impact of the project? 

Transform space debris into a commercialized product by turning them into raw material to be sold on Earth, benefiting both the space market as well as ensuring safety to the future missions. 

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project? 

N/A

How is your project creative? 

The search for innovation and the need of a solution to the space debris overflow are combined though an effective solution in the execution of this project in reason of both the approach to the recycling matter but also addressing the lack of specific raw materials.

What factors did your team consider?

The need for solution to this reoccurring problem in LEO, redirecting what would potentially become an obstacle for space navigation and exploration into a product to be commercialized on Earth.

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. projectDetails.name: Project FarmFlux
projectDetails.summary:
Farm Flux is an interactive educational game that simulates sustainable agriculture using real NASA satellite data from the POWER API. Players manage virtual farms by making data-driven decisions about crop planting, irrigation, fertilization, and livestock management based on actual climate conditions.

The game addresses the NASA Farm Navigators challenge by integrating real-time temperature, precipitation, humidity, and wind data to demonstrate how satellite information can inform modern agricultural practices. Players learn the environmental and economic impacts of their decisions through a sustainability scoring system (Grade A-F) and educational feedback.

This matters because it bridges the gap between space technology and practical farming education. By visualizing 30-day climate trends and showing how weather directly affects crop growth, Farm Flux teaches farmers, students, and agricultural professionals how NASA's open data can optimize resource efficiency and promote sustainable farming methods—crucial for food security in a changing climate.
projectDetails.details:
Farm Flux is an interactive web-based agricultural simulation game that integrates real-time NASA satellite data to teach sustainable farming practices. Players create virtual farms at real GPS coordinates and make data-driven decisions about crop management, irrigation, fertilization, and livestock handling.

Core Mechanics:

  • Players input farm coordinates (e.g., São Paulo: -23.5505, -46.6333)
  • NASA POWER API fetches real climate data (temperature, precipitation, humidity, wind) using MERRA-2 satellite measurements
  • Players plant crops (corn, wheat, soybean, rice, cotton) that grow automatically based on actual weather conditions
  • Every agricultural activity (9 types: organic/chemical fertilization, drip/sprinkler/flood irrigation, rotational/free-range/intensive grazing) generates educational feedback and impacts sustainability scores
  • 30-day climate trend charts visualize temperature and rainfall patterns
  • Sustainability scoring system (Grade A-F) evaluates environmental impact

🌟 Benefits & Impact

Educational Benefits:

  1. Data Literacy: Students learn to interpret NASA satellite data for practical applications
  2. Sustainability Awareness: Visual feedback shows environmental consequences of farming choices
  3. Climate Understanding: 30-day trend charts demonstrate weather patterns' impact on agriculture
  4. Decision Making: Players balance economic costs vs. environmental sustainability

Real-World Impact:

  • For Farmers: Demonstrates how free NASA data can optimize resource efficiency (water, fertilizer)
  • For Students: Gamified learning about precision agriculture and climate science
  • For Educators: Ready-to-use tool for teaching sustainable agriculture concepts
  • For Communities: Promotes food security awareness in changing climate conditions

🛠️ Technology Stack

Backend:

  • Laravel 12.0 (PHP 8.4) - Game logic, NASA API integration
  • SQLite/MySQL - Storing farms, crops, weather data, activities
  • Composer - Dependency management

Frontend:

  • Vue 3.5 (TypeScript) - Reactive UI components
  • Inertia.js 2.0 - SPA framework bridging Laravel & Vue
  • Vite 7.0 - Fast HMR (Hot Module Replacement)
  • Tailwind CSS 4.1 - Responsive styling
  • Chart.js - Data visualization (30-day climate trends)
  • Reka UI - Accessible component library
  • Lucide Icons - Modern icon system

External APIs:

  • NASA POWER API - Real satellite data from MERRA-2 (Modern-Era Retrospective Analysis)
  • Parameters fetched: T2M (temperature), PRECTOTCORR (precipitation), RH2M (humidity), WS2M (wind speed)

DevOps:

  • Git - Version control
  • NPM - Frontend package management
  • Artisan - Laravel CLI for migrations, seeding, commands

🎨 Creative Elements

1. Gamification Design:

  • Emoji-based feedback system (✅🌍💧⚠️💡) makes learning engaging
  • Grade system (A-F) inspired by academic scoring for familiarity
  • Toast notifications provide instant gratification/warning
  • Progress bars visualize abstract concepts (soil quality, water level)

2. Data Visualization Innovation:

  • Dual-axis chart: Temperature line + precipitation bars in one view
  • Trend badges (🔥 Warming / 🧊 Cooling / ⚖️ Stable) simplify complex climate data
  • Color coding: Red (hot/critical), blue (water), green (healthy), orange (warning)

3. Educational Approach:

  • Contextual tips: "Drip irrigation saves up to 50% more water than traditional methods"
  • Predictive feedback: "Optimal weather for fertilization! Plants can best absorb nutrients now"
  • Comparative costs: Shows economic vs. environmental trade-offs ($50-$200/hectare)

4. Realistic Simulation:

  • Automatic crop growth based on real weather (runs hourly via Laravel scheduler)
  • Growth stages: seedling → vegetative → flowering → ripening → mature
  • Harvest readiness: Crops mature only after sufficient days + favorable conditions

🧠 Design Considerations

1. Accessibility:

  • Keyboard navigation: Full ARIA support via Reka UI components
  • Screen reader friendly: Semantic HTML, proper labels
  • Tooltips: Hover and focus states for information
  • Color contrast: WCAG AA compliant

2. Performance:

  • API caching: Weather data cached to minimize NASA API calls
  • Lazy loading: Components load on-demand
  • Optimistic UI updates: Instant feedback while API processes
  • Debounced inputs: Form validation doesn't trigger on every keystroke

3. Scalability:

  • Modular architecture: Services pattern (NasaWeatherService, FarmSimulationService)
  • Database migrations: Version-controlled schema changes
  • Factory & Seeders: Easy demo data generation
  • Policy-based authorization: Secure multi-user support ready

4. User Experience:

  • Empty states: Motivational messages when no crops planted
  • Loading states: Skeleton loaders prevent jarring content shifts
  • Error handling: Friendly messages instead of technical errors
  • Progressive disclosure: Advanced features revealed gradually

5. Educational Integrity:

  • Real data only: No fake/simulated climate data
  • Scientific accuracy: Fertilizer/irrigation impacts based on agricultural research
  • Transparent sources: NASA API parameters clearly documented
  • Balanced messaging: Shows benefits AND drawbacks of each method

🌍 Global Applicability

Multi-Region Support:

  • Works with any GPS coordinates globally
  • NASA POWER API covers entire planet
  • Players can compare farms in different climates (e.g., Brazil vs. India)

Localization Ready:

  • Metric system (hectares, Celsius, mm, m/s)
  • Internationalization (i18n) structure prepared for multiple languages

📊 Impact Metrics

Measurable Outcomes:

  • Sustainability Score: Quantifies environmental impact (0-100)
  • Resource Efficiency: Tracks water usage, fertilizer application
  • Yield Optimization: Compares actual vs. potential harvest
  • Cost-Benefit Analysis: Shows $/hectare vs. sustainability trade-offs

Long-term Vision:

  • Export farm reports for educational portfolios
  • Leaderboard to encourage competition
  • Achievement system to reward sustainable practices
  • Multiplayer mode for collaborative learning

All critical decisions remained human:

AI accelerated routine tasks, allowing me to focus on creative problem-solving and educational value.

projectDetails.name: Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE)
projectDetails.summary:
Low Earth Orbit (LEO) is on the verge of an unprecedented expansion. The European Space Agency (ESA) projects that the number of active satellites will rise from about 7,500 today to over 100,000 by 2035, a 1,200% increase that dramatically heightens the risk of collisions and chain fragmentation, the Kessler Syndrome.
NASA’s LEGEND and ESA’s MASTER models indicate that, without active mitigation, collision probabilities could rise fivefold within two decades, creating tens of thousands of new debris fragments and threatening the entire commercial use of LEO.

The Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE) transforms this challenge into opportunity by creating the world’s first financial market for orbital sustainability.
Inspired by carbon credits, OCE introduces “orbital credits”, tradable assets that reward debris removal and charge for orbital usage.
If only 1% of annual satellite launches participate, OCE could enable the removal or recycling of 2,000–5,000 debris objects per year, reducing orbital density by 15–20% within 15 years.
By aligning sustainability with profitability, OCE ensures that space remains safe, accessible, and economically vibrant for generations to come.
projectDetails.details:
Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE)

What does it do or how does it work?
The Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE) transforms orbital debris removal from a cost with no clear market into a sustainable economic ecosystem. Inspired by carbon markets, OCE introduces “orbital credits”:

  • Satellite operators pay orbital fees based on mass and time in orbit.
  • Missions (public, private, or academic) that remove or recycle debris earn credits.
  • Credits can be traded in a transparent digital marketplace, creating an economic incentive for Active Debris Removal (ADR).

A web application prototype demonstrates this mechanism: operators manage their orbital balance, ADR missions simulate debris removal, and a marketplace enables credit trading. Blockchain integration ensures trust and transparency across international stakeholders.

What benefits does it have?

  • Economic Incentive: Creates a real financial driver for debris removal, solving the current lack of motivation.
  • Sustainability: Promotes circular use of orbital resources by rewarding recycling and reuse.
  • Transparency: Blockchain-backed credits guarantee trust across agencies, companies, and citizens.
  • Scalability: As more satellites are launched, the market naturally grows.
  • Collaboration: Engages governments, startups, investors, and the public in a shared framework.

What is the intended impact of the project?
The OCE establishes the first global financial market for orbital sustainability. Its impact goes beyond technology:

  • The Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE) has the potential to reduce orbital debris density by up to 20% over 15 years by funding the removal or recycling of up to 5,000 objects per year, even with participation from just 1% of annual global satellite launches.
  • Encourages responsible orbital usage and end-of-life (EOL) planning.
  • Reduces the risk of collisions and cascade effects (Kessler Syndrome).
  • Attracts ESG investors and creates a new space economy sector.
  • Raises global awareness by allowing citizens and crowdfunding initiatives to participate in orbital clean-up.

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

  • Lovable.app

How is your project creative?

  • Novel Market Mechanism: First to apply the proven concept of carbon credits to space sustainability.
  • Inclusive Participation: Not limited to agencies—startups, universities, and citizens can take part.
  • Integration of Multiple Layers: Combines economics, ESG principles, blockchain trust, and orbital data in a single ecosystem.
  • Educational Impact: Serves as a tool to demonstrate orbital sustainability concepts to the general public.

What factors did your team consider?

  • Scalability: Designed to grow as satellite constellations expand.
  • Feasibility: Balance between ambitious goals (debris recycling, blockchain) and hackathon-ready prototypes (mock APIs, simulations).
  • Trust: Blockchain integration ensures international adoption potential.
  • Stakeholder Diversity: Operators, agencies, ADR missions, and investors all have defined roles.
  • Sustainability & Circularity: Ensures companies are accountable for orbital usage while encouraging innovation in debris recycling.

challengeDetails.title: Commercializing Low Earth Orbit (LEO)
challengeDetails.excerpt: As the commercialization of space rapidly accelerates, the future of business in low Earth orbit (LEO) holds incredible potential, but also presents significant operational, regulatory, and environmental challenges. This new economic frontier invites innovative and sustainable approaches to foster long-term viability and responsible execution. Your challenge is to conceptualize and design a scalable, sustainable, business model, accompanied by a prototype, that explores the unique opportunities LEO offers while addressing the complexities of operating in space. (Joint Agency Satellite Division)

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI

With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

node.title: Gatonautas
node.excerpt: We are a team passionate about science, technology, and space exploration. Our chosen challenge is Hunting for Exoplanets with AI.  And our goal is to create an accurate and accessible solution that can support researchers and contribute to democr...

projectDetails.name: Project Space Cats
projectDetails.summary: Applying machine learning to astronomical research can be complex and often out of reach. That’s why we aim to make exoplanet discovery accessible through a website with an intuitive, beginner-friendly interface, while still providing advanced features for researchers. Beyond data analysis, we also offer tools designed for both theoretical understanding and practical learning, empowering users to explore, experiment, and grow, because we believe that by bringing science to people, we can bring people to science.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do or how does it work?

Our project processes raw light curves obtained from a CSV file, running them through a custom-built pipeline designed to extract key features (such as orbital period, transit duration, and depth). Using these extracted features, a pre-trained machine learning model — trained on NASA’s public light curve datasets processed through our own pipeline — predicts whether each light curve corresponds to a planet candidate, non-candidate, or confirmed planet (if matched with any known catalog entry).


All these capabilities are integrated into an intuitive web interface, which also includes an educational section that introduces exoplanet concepts in an engaging and gamified way, making learning fun and accessible.

Users can also manually classify plotted light curves through an interactive tool — their classifications are collected and statistically analyzed to continuously improve the machine learning models over time.

What benefits does it have?

Our project bridges the gap between professionals and newcomers in exoplanetary science. It enables both researchers without strong programming backgrounds and enthusiasts who are curious about space science to analyze and interact with real astronomical data through a web interface, while also contributing directly to model improvement.

What is the intended impact of the project?

We aim to create a tool that not only assists in the detection and classification of exoplanets but also promotes scientific outreach by democratizing access to space science. By lowering the technical barrier and integrating user contributions into the process, we hope to inspire new participants to engage with exoplanet research and data-driven astronomy.

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

We used Python (and its scientific libraries) for data processing, feature extraction, and machine learning model training, as well as for the backend implementation. The frontend was developed using React, allowing for a dynamic, responsive, and interactive user experience.

How is your project creative?

The creativity of this project lies in merging two complementary goals: providing a functional research tool for scientific use, and creating an interactive educational platform for learners. It transforms a traditionally technical field into an accessible and collaborative experience for anyone interested in contributing to space science.

What factors did your team consider?

Our team focused on addressing the current imbalance in the field of astronomy, where interest in exoplanet discovery is high, but the entry barrier due to required programming and data analysis skills remains steep. We aimed to design a solution that empowers users at all levels to participate meaningfully in space exploration.

GitHub project: https://github.com/Mykaell-Max/Gatonautas
projectDetails.aiReferences:
All core ideas and project structure were conceived and implemented by our team.
AI tools (such as ChatGPT) were used to assist in research, generate code templates, and improve efficiency during development — for example, by helping structure functions, optimize syntax, and explore different programming approaches.

challengeDetails.title: SpaceTrash Hack: Revolutionizing Recycling on Mars
challengeDetails.excerpt: During a hypothetical three-year mission to Mars and back, an eight-person crew would accumulate 12,600 kg of inorganic waste, or trash, including various packaging materials, textiles, and structural materials. This scenario creates a pressing need to recycle available materials, rather than execute the expensive and inefficient processes of transporting additional resources from Earth and/or sending trash back to Earth. As humans prepare to explore unknown worlds in the future, your challenge is to design sustainable systems that could manage, reuse, or recycle inorganic waste (“trash”) that is brought to and/or accumulated on the surface of Mars. Space habitat concepts can involve a diverse array of materials, geometries, and layouts. Your challenge is to create a visual tool that enables users to define a space habitat’s shape/volume and explore possible layout options. (Exploration Systems Development Mission Directorate)

projectDetails.name: Quality Air
projectDetails.summary:
The "Quality Ar" project forecasts Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2) levels and the corresponding air quality index in São Paulo. Using historical data from the CETESB Pinheiros monitoring station, it allows users to check air quality predictions for specific future dates.

This tool addresses the challenge of urban pollution by enabling citizens, especially vulnerable groups, to take preventive health measures against high pollution days. Its importance lies in democratizing access to environmental data, raising awareness, and helping people make informed decisions to protect their health.
projectDetails.details:
The benefits:

  • Accurate forecast of NO2
  • A study to define public policies to support people with or at risk of respiratory diseases.
  • A study to improve air quality and understand the main emitters of hazardous gases.

Tools:

  • Python for data analysis, neural network training, forecast NO2 at N dates.
  • Java for scrape data from CETESB Qualar
  • React Native for frontend.

Hardware:

  • PCs with GPU dedicated to train and test the models
  • Dedicated Server to Host the backend and frontend

projectDetails.name: Project KOIKWA
projectDetails.summary:
Koikwa 1 – Buraco no Céu is an educational Internet of Things (IoT) project designed to simulate satellite data acquisition and analysis. The system measures local environmental conditions—specifically temperature—using a BMP180 sensor connected to a Heltec V3 microcontroller, and compares these ground-based readings with satellite-derived temperature estimates from NASA’s POWER (Prediction of Worldwide Energy Resources) dataset.

Additionally, the project integrates a u-blox M10 GPS module to record geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude), ensuring accurate spatial correlation between local and satellite data. Data is transmitted via Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) in real time to a connected application, where it is stored, visualized through dynamic graphs, and analyzed statistically to highlight variations and trends.

The overarching mission of Koikwa 1 – Buraco no Céu is to inspire scientific curiosity and technological learning among children by providing a hands-on demonstration of how IoT technologies and open-access satellite data can be combined to explore environmental science in an accessible and engaging way.
projectDetails.details: The project aims to simulate the reading of satellite data by comparing temperature measurements obtained from the BMP180 sensor with information from NASA POWER, while also displaying latitude and longitude data using the u-blox M10 GPS module, with both the module and sensor controlled by the ESP32-S3 microcontroller.

projectDetails.name: Project Koikwa 2
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, Koikwa 2 - Cotton Rope, is a space lander prototype designed as an educational tool for instrumentation, embedded electronics, sensing, and programming. We developed a system using a BBC micro:bit board and an HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor to map surfaces by acquiring real-time distance and magnetic field data. The micro:bit's internal magnetometer measures the magnetic field, providing orientation and composition data, while the ultrasonic sensor determines the lander's altitude and maps the surface topography.
This prototype directly addresses the challenge by providing a hands-on, low-cost platform for learning essential space exploration technologies. Our project is deeply inspired by the origin story of the Kayapó people of Brazil, whose ancestors descended from the sky on a long cotton rope. In their story, the stars represent their celestial ancestors. Our lander's descent to map a new world mirrors this mythological journey. This connection is important as it bridges modern space science with the rich, ancient cosmology of indigenous cultures, reminding us that the quest to understand our origins and explore new frontiers is a timeless, universal human endeavor.
projectDetails.details:
Inspiration: A Bridge Between Worlds

Our project is deeply rooted in the powerful origin story of the Mebêngôkre (Kayapó) people, an indigenous ethnicity from our home region in Uberlândia, Brazil. Their cosmology tells of ancestors who lived in the sky until a warrior discovered a passage to Earth. Enchanted by the world below, they decided to descend using a long rope made of cotton. For them, the stars are their celestial ancestors, a nightly reminder of their origins.

Our lander's mission—to descend from above and map an unknown world—is a direct technological parallel to this ancient journey. Our "Cotton Rope" is the stream of data connecting our probe to our control station. The goal of Koikwa 2 is to create a project that is not only scientifically functional but also rich in meaning, connecting the drive for space exploration with humanity's oldest stories about the cosmos.

How It Works: The Technical Mission

Koikwa 2 is a functional prototype built to demonstrate the core principles of a planetary lander's survey mission.

  • Hardware Core: The brain of our lander is a BBC micro:bit, a versatile and accessible microcontroller. It's connected to an HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor, which acts as a simple altimeter and surface scanner. The entire system is powered by a 3.7V LiPo battery, making it a self-contained unit.
    1. Topographical Mapping: The HC-SR04 sensor emits ultrasonic pulses and measures the time it takes for the echo to return. Our code converts this time into a precise distance measurement, allowing the lander to map the height and contours of the surface below it.
    2. Magnetic Field Analysis: Simultaneously, the micro:bit’s onboard magnetometer gathers magnetic field data (X, Y, Z axes). This data can be used to determine the lander's orientation and could potentially detect magnetic anomalies on a planetary surface.
  • Software & Data Stream: The firmware was developed in MicroPython, valued for its simplicity and power. The lander outputs a continuous stream of comma-separated values (CSV) in the format distance_cm, magnetic_field_x, magnetic_field_y, magnetic_field_z via a serial connection. This raw data can be easily logged, parsed, and visualized using simple scripts or even spreadsheet software.


How Our Project Addresses the Challenge

Koikwa 2 directly addresses the challenge of creating educational tools for space science in several ways:

  • Accessibility & Low Cost: It uses off-the-shelf, affordable components, making space science accessible to students, hobbyists, and educators without large budgets.
  • Hands-On Learning: It provides a tangible platform for learning fundamental skills in electronics, programming (MicroPython), sensor integration, and data analysis—the very skills needed for a career in aerospace.
  • Inspiration & STEAM: By connecting STEM with the Arts and Humanities (the "A" in STEAM), our project provides a powerful narrative hook to engage a wider and more diverse audience in the wonders of space exploration.

projectDetails.name: Wind of Changes - Kultive 2025
projectDetails.summary:
Começo dos Trabalhos !
O vento é um fenômeno natural crucial que influencia o clima, transporta sementes, forma ondas no mar e é uma fonte de energia renovável. Ele se forma pelo deslocamento do ar de áreas de alta pressão para as de baixa pressão, causado pelo aquecimento desigual do planeta. O vento pode ser tão forte que atinge centenas de quilômetros por hora em eventos como tornados, e sua força também pode criar o som característico, seja o assobio de turbulências ou o bater de objeto.
No espaço sideral, o vento solar é o movimento através do espaço de gases e partículas carregadas emitidas pelo Sol, enquanto que o vento planetário é a desgaseificação de elementos químicos leves a partir da atmosfera de um planeta em direção ao espaço. Os ventos são geralmente classificados de acordo com a sua escala, rapidez, tipos de forças que os provocam, regiões em que ocorrem e com o seu efeito. Os ventos de maior intensidade observados no sistema solar ocorrem em Neptuno e Saturno.  https://pt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vento
projectDetails.details:
Funcionalidades do aplicativo a ser desenvolvido

Deverá ser fornecido o local e a data da previsão:

Análise de IA:

Utiliza A IA para gerar uma análise textual criativa e espirituosa sobre o clima.

Previsão Baseada em Dados Reais:

A IA consulta a API Open-Meteo para obter dados meteorológicos em tempo real (temperatura, umidade, vento), tornando a análise mais precisa.

O Open-Meteo utiliza uma poderosa combinação de modelos meteorológicos globais (11 km) e de mesoescala (1 km) de renomados serviços meteorológicos nacionais, fornecendo previsões abrangentes com precisão notável.

Não importa onde você esteja no mundo, você pode acessar as previsões meteorológicas mais confiáveis ​​e precisas disponíveis.

Os dados meteorológicos são apresentados em resolução horária, permitindo que você planeje suas atividades com confiança.

Os primeiros dias da previsão se beneficiam de modelos meteorológicos localizados, que oferecem informações altamente detalhadas e precisas. Posteriormente, modelos meteorológicos globais fornecem previsões para até 16 dias. Por meio de integração perfeita, nossas APIs oferecem uma experiência de previsão do tempo horária simples e confiável.

Além disso, os dados são licenciados sob a Atribuição 4.0 Internacional (CC BY 4.0) .

Isso significa que você tem liberdade para compartilhar e adaptar os dados, mesmo para fins comerciais.

Elas são baseadas no protocolo HTTP amplamente adotado e utilizam a simplicidade do formato de dados JSON.

Tudo o que você precisa para começar é um conhecimento básico de coordenadas geográficas,

como fazer solicitações HTTP e trabalhar com dados JSON.

https://open-meteo.com/en/docs

Medidor de "Estraga-Festa":

Exibe a probabilidade (0-100%) de condições adversas como

"Muito Quente", "Muito Frio", "Muito Vento", etc.

Mapa Interativo:

Camadas de Satélite:

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: The Secrets of Space Weather
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, “The Secrets of Space Weather”, focuses on teaching kids about space weather through a fun and educational game. The main goal is to make complex scientific concepts, such as solar flares, CMEs, radiation storms, and their effects on Earth, accessible and engaging for young learners. We developed an interactive digital game that combines storytelling, colorful visuals, and simple challenges to encourage curiosity and understanding of how the Sun influences our planet.

To address the challenge of limited awareness and education about space weather among children, "The Secrets of Space Weather" uses gamified learning techniques and playful interaction. The game provides short missions where players learn about solar activity and understand the importance of space weather in our lives. This approach transforms abstract scientific data into relatable, hands-on experiences.

"The Secrets of Space Weather" is important because it bridges the gap between science and education, inspiring the next generation to explore astronomy and space science. By presenting real scientific ideas in a creative and age-appropriate way, the project promotes STEM education (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) and helps build a foundation for future scientific curiosity and understanding.
projectDetails.details:
The mysteries of space weather and its influence on Earth are often seen as complex and distant subjects, but they can directly affect our daily lives. Solar flares, coronal mass ejections, and geomagnetic storms can interfere with communication systems, navigation, and even power grids. Despite their importance, these phenomena are rarely explored in an accessible way for young audiences.

To change this, we created “The Secrets of Space Weather”, a digital educational game  that combines science, art, and narrative to introduce children and teenagers aged 10 to 15 years to the fascinating world of space weather — in a fun and interactive way.

The story follows Luma, a curious girl passionate about science who embarks on a journey guided by her scientist friend, Dr.Brall, to discover what space weather is and how it affects people around the world. Across three exciting phases, Luma meets different characters such as a pilot struggling with signal loss, a photographer chasing auroras, and astronauts facing dangerous solar radiation. Throughout these, Luma meets not only people impacted by the space weather but also the personified phenomena themselves.

Each event, like a Solar Flare, an Aurora Borealis or a Radiation Storm, becomes a living character who explains its origins and behavior. These unique interactions allow children to learn from both sides of the story: the people who experience the effects and the solar phenomena that cause them. Each encounter includes playful dialogues that translate scientific concepts into easy understanding comparisons and mini-games that reinforce learning in a fun way.

What makes our solution unique is its creative and emotional approach. The personification of solar events gives them memorable and relatable personalities that help children connect emotionally with scientific ideas. Through visual metaphors and everyday analogies, the game connects abstract physics to the child’s own world, making learning intuitive and inspiring.

Unlike traditional educational materials, our game does not just explain — it invites the player to live science, allowing children to actively participate in the narrative, helping characters and solving thematic mini-games. This promotes active learning, critical thinking, and curiosity through play. 

Another key differentiator is the balanced portrayal of space weather’s dual nature — its challenges, like radiation and interference, and its beauty, like the auroras that paint the sky. Few educational materials highlight this duality, and our game does so in a way that sparks wonder, empathy, and environmental awareness.

Beyond entertainment, the game has strong educational potential. It can be integrated into classrooms or informal learning environments as a support tool for science education and space literacy, encouraging new generations to become interested in astronomy, physics, and environmental awareness.

Our current version functions as a pilot project with three stages, designed to demonstrate the game’s educational potential and scalability. Future levels can be created to expand this universe, introducing new challenges such as helping a power grid operator redirect Geomagnetically Induced Currents (GICs) to protect transformers from failures caused by Geomagnetic Disturbances (GMDs); assisting a space traffic engineer in maneuvering satellites to compensate for increased atmospheric drag driven by Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) and neutral density (ND) expansion; or even supporting a farmer in stabilizing GNSS signals to ensure precise planting despite signal scintillation during a geomagnetic storm. This progressive expansion highlights the real-world diversity of space weather impacts, demonstrating the game’s potential to grow further while educating players about some of the most fascinating space phenomena.

The project was developed using Kripta for character and environment design and Godot 4.5 as the main game engine, with GDScript as the primary programming language. The Dialogic plugin was implemented to manage the interactive storytelling system. Team collaboration was supported through Discord for communication and Git/GitHub for version control and code synchronization.

The educational content is based on NASA data, which provided the scientific foundation to explain key space weather concepts such as solar flares, aurora borealis, radiation storms, coronal mass ejections (CMEs), and the solar activity cycle. The design of the game’s levels and missions — such as helping a transatlantic pilot after a solar flare or saving astronauts facing dangerous solar radiation — was created by insights from a NASA survey on user needs for space weather, ensuring the gameplay aligns with realistic scenarios and practical understanding.

The game's design is directly inspired by the Results of the First National Survey of User Needs for Space Weather (NASA resource) report, which outlines user needs and critical impacts across seven sectors important to national security, the economy, and society. The idea was to transform documented space weather threats into a dynamic challenges. For instance, the Aviation Sector phase mirrors the real-world operational need to mitigate risks from Solar Flares that cause HF communication outages (Radio Blackouts), forcing the player to execute the maneuver of diverting the aircraft to safer routes, replicating actions taken by some air carriers during events like the Gannon Storm. By translating these specific, identified sector vulnerabilities and the documented need for improved education and awareness into dynamic mechanics the game directly contributes to the overarching goal of enhancing national resilience to space weather.

Ultimately, “The Secrets of Space Weather” seeks to make space science accessible, emotional, and inspiring. By transforming NASA’s research into a living adventure, combining visual design, gameplay mechanics, and verified space weather data, our project not only educates but also cultivates the next generation’s curiosity about the Sun–Earth connection, motivating young minds to explore, discover, and protect the world around them — from the ground to the stars — with wonder and understanding.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used AI (ChatGPT version 5.0) primarily to assist with translation, text refinement, and generating ideas for the project script. Additionally, AI was employed to troubleshoot technical issues and suggest improvements in code.

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Lobotomia Soluções
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, Astral Leucotome, is an interactive, web-based simulation tool that models the regional consequences of an asteroid impact on Earth. We developed a Python Flask backend that serves as the scientific engine, coupled with a dynamic JavaScript frontend that provides intuitive controls and a map-based interface for visualizing the outcomes.
This tool directly addresses the challenge by allowing users to select real asteroids from NASA's API or customize their own theoretical impactor. The backend calculates a suite of environmental effects using physics-based models, including crater dimensions, kinetic energy, seismic magnitude, and air blast radius. These calculations are based on established scientific principles, such as the Gutenberg-Richter relation for seismic shaking and yield scaling for the air blast. Users can also simulate a kinetic impactor mitigation mission, demonstrating how a spacecraft can alter an asteroid's velocity.
The importance of this project lies in its ability to make the abstract threat of an asteroid impact tangible and accessible. By translating complex scientific data into clear, visual consequences, it serves as a powerful educational tool for the public, students, and policymakers, effectively underscoring the critical importance of planetary defense initiatives.
projectDetails.details:
What It Does & How It Works

Astral Leucotome is a web-based simulation tool that calculates and visualizes the regional environmental consequences of an asteroid impact on Earth. It operates on a client-server architecture:

  • Backend: A robust API built with Python and the Flask framework serves as the scientific engine. It receives simulation parameters, fetches real-time data on near-Earth objects from NASA's NeoWs API, and processes it through a pipeline of physics modules. These modules calculate the asteroid's kinetic energy, the resulting crater dimensions, the equivalent seismic magnitude (using the Gutenberg-Richter relation), and the radius of the air-blast shockwave based on scientific models from papers like Collins et al. (2005). The backend also includes an endpoint to simulate a kinetic impactor mitigation mission.
  • Frontend: A dynamic, interactive interface built with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript (using jQuery, Leaflet, Bootstrap, D3 and TreeJS) provides the user experience. Users can either select a real asteroid from a searchable list or customize a theoretical impactor using sliders for mass, diameter, and velocity. They can then choose an impact point by dragging and dropping an icon onto an interactive world map, triggering the simulation and visualizing the results.

The primary benefit of our project is its educational power. It demystifies the complex science of asteroid impacts, making the abstract threat tangible and accessible to a broad audience, from students to policymakers. By transforming raw scientific data into clear visual outputs—such as concentric circles for the crater and shockwave on a map—the tool effectively communicates the scale of a potential disaster.

The intended impact is threefold:

  1. Raise Public Awareness: To foster a greater public understanding of the real, albeit low-probability, risk of an asteroid impact.
  2. Support Decision-Making: To provide a "what-if" sandbox where users can explore the consequences of an impact in a specific location, highlighting the need for and effectiveness of planetary defense.
  3. Inspire Interest in Science: To create an engaging, hands-on experience that encourages exploration and learning in the fields of physics, geology, and planetary science.

Tools, Languages, and Software

  • Backend:
    • Languages: Python
    • Frameworks/Libraries: Flask (for the web server), Flasgger (for OpenAPI/Swagger documentation), SQLAlchemy (for caching), python-dotenv (for environment management).
    • Languages: HTML, CSS, JavaScript
    • Frameworks/Libraries: Bootstrap (for styling and layout), jQuery (for DOM manipulation), Leaflet (for the interactive 2D map), D3.js and Three.js (for dynamic data visualizations and 3D rendering).
    • Version Control: Git, GitHub
    • IDE: Visual Studio Code
    • Deployment/Tunneling: ngrok (for development and sharing).

The project's creativity lies in its transformation of static scientific research into a dynamic, hands-on learning experience. Instead of reading a complex paper, a user can directly engage with the physics. The combination of a searchable database of real asteroids with fully customizable "what-if" scenarios provides both realism and creative freedom. The drag-and-drop interface for selecting an impact location is an intuitive and engaging method that immediately connects the simulation to a familiar geographical context, making the results far more personal and impactful.

Factors Considered

Our team prioritized several key factors during development:

  • Scientific Accuracy: We based our core calculations on peer-reviewed scientific literature, specifically the models presented by Collins, Melosh, & Marcus (2005) for impact effects and the Gutenberg-Richter relation for seismic magnitude. We made simplifications where necessary for the hackathon but always started from an established scientific basis.
  • User Experience (UX): We focused on creating an intuitive interface. The use of sliders for input, real-time calculation feedback, and clear visual outputs on a map were all deliberate choices to make the tool easy and engaging to use without prior scientific knowledge.
  • Modularity and Scalability: The backend was designed with a clear separation of concerns (data fetching, energetics, cratering, effects), making the code easier to manage, test, and extend in the future.
  • Team Collaboration: We utilized a feature-branching workflow in Git to allow for parallel development on the frontend and various backend modules, which was critical for making significant progress in a short amount of time.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
We utilized Google's Gemini, ass an AI-powered tutor, and technical consultant throughout the hackathon. The AI's role was to accelerate development and assist in overcoming technical challenges, allowing our team to focus on the project's vision, design, and scientific integration.

Specifically, AI was used in the following areas:

  • Conceptualization and Scientific Modeling: Assisting in the interpretation of the project's scientific documents, explaining complex physics concepts (such as kinetic energy, overpressure, and NAT loopback), and helping select and implement appropriate simplified formulas (like the Gutenberg-Richter relation and cube root scaling for air blasts) for the hackathon's scope.
  • Debugging: Providing real-time assistance in diagnosing and solving a wide range of issues
  • Best Practices and Documentation: Aiding in the formulation of conventional Git commit messages, explaining team collaboration workflows (feature branching), translating code comments, and assisting in the drafting of the final project summaries and descriptions.

All AI-generated code and concepts were reviewed, understood, and integrated by the team members.

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: A.I.M. - Aegis Impact Model
projectDetails.summary: A.I.M. (Aegis Impact Model) is a visualization and predictive system designed to simulate and analyze scenarios in which celestial bodies collide with Earth. The platform leverages Large Language Models (LLMs) to generate analytical reports based on the selected impact location, detailing instantaneous, economic, and environmental consequences, as well as physical parameters such as released energy and impact radius. Users can fully customize meteor parameters, including composition, diameter (0–100 km), velocity, and impact angle, enabling the exploration of a wide range of collision scenarios across different regions of the planet. The project aims to serve as both a scientific and exploratory tool, providing a dynamic environment for impact assessment and educational visualization. Future expanded versions of A.I.M. are envisioned to incorporate pre-impact prediction and post-impact analysis, creating a comprehensive framework for understanding and modeling the complete lifecycle of meteor events.
projectDetails.details:
INTRODUCTION

According to the Statistical Discovery Report from the Center for Near-Earth Object Studies (CNEOS), nearly 40,000 Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) have been discovered to date. With a significant number of these bodies passing close to Earth, and with recorded impact events such as the Chelyabinsk Event (2013), the study and prediction of potential impact scenarios are of critical importance. Accurate forecasting of such events has the potential to mitigate risks and ultimately save lives.

[Image 1 - CNEOS Close Approach Visualization 2025 SY10]

THE NECESSITY

Given the vast number of objects passing near Earth, the probability of collisions with our planet remains a significant parameter to consider. Through the use of advanced computational and analytical technologies, predicting all possible impact scenarios based on an asteroid’s physical composition and trajectory becomes an invaluable approach to mitigating potential threats.

From an educational perspective, such a tool could serve as an exceptional resource for academic research, classroom studies, and scientific outreach, enhancing understanding of celestial dynamics and planetary defense.

THE SOLUTION

Powered by artificial intelligence, A.I.M. can generate a comprehensive range of statistical and analytical data that may assist governmental and environmental agencies in mitigating the environmental, economic, and social impacts of potential meteor events within a given region.

[Image 2 - A.I.M.'s Main Screen]

Beyond its scientific applications, the system also serves as a valuable educational platform for universities, schools, and research institutions, expanding knowledge about asteroids while enabling users to simulate and analyze real-world problem-solving scenarios.

[Image 3 - A.I.M.'s Config Screen]

The DEMO version of A.I.M. allows for full customization of meteor parameters, supporting diameters of up to 100 kilometers, thereby encompassing not only minor but also catastrophic impact scenarios. It features an interactive 3D visualization of the Earth, providing a highly immersive simulation experience.

For the development of this DEMO, Gemini 2.5 Flash was employed to process and interpret data based on the user-selected impact location, ensuring accuracy and dynamic adaptation of simulated conditions.

[Image 4 - A.I.M.'s DEMO A.I. Report]

TECHNOLOGIES UTILIZED

The A.I.M. system integrates AI-powered and map visualization APIs, while maintaining a lightweight core architecture built primarily with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. These core technologies handle the rendering, styling, and mathematical computations required to visualize impact radius and released energy based on the meteor’s defined parameters.

The web application is deployed on Vercel and fully integrated with GitHub for continuous development and version control. Its core logic is implemented in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, while external APIs including Gemini 2.5 Flash for AI-driven data interpretation and Mapbox for geospatial visualization extend its analytical and interactive capabilities.

[Image 5 - Application Architeture Diagram]

Future Improvements

  • Advanced AI Integration: Implement more sophisticated AI models to generate highly detailed and statistically accurate reports, including graphical visualizations, data tables, and potentially proposed mitigation strategies for different impact scenarios.
  • Integration of a Meteor Database: Incorporate a database of scientifically catalogued meteors to enhance simulation realism and expand configuration parameters, allowing users to analyze real-world impact cases with precise physical data.
  • Enhanced Map Data Visualization: Enrich the map interface with additional environmental and physical data, such as detailed information about the impact radius, shockwave propagation, tsunami generation, and seismic activity associated with the simulated event.

Conclusion

The A.I.M. (Aegis Impact Model) serves as a foundational step toward the development of a modular and comprehensive system for the prediction and simulation of meteor impacts. Designed as both a scientific and educational tool, it aims to democratize access to impact analyses and case studies, allowing users from various fields to explore the potential consequences of celestial collisions in an interactive and data-driven environment.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
During the development of this project, artificial intelligence played a key role in several areas:

  • Report Generation: The Gemini 2.5 Flash API served as an essential tool for producing predictive reports based on the user-selected impact location, providing detailed analyses of potential consequences.
  • Content Review and Ideation: ChatGPT 5.0 contributed to textual review, refinement, and idea generation, supporting the project’s conceptual development and enhancing the clarity and quality of documentation.

projectDetails.name: Project EcoPulse
projectDetails.summary:
Our project aims to improve access to healthcare and promote sustainability in Uberlândia, focusing on vulnerable areas with limited infrastructure that are sensitive to extreme climate variations. The lack of accessible healthcare facilities and the worsening of health conditions due to climate change are critical challenges. To mitigate these problems, we propose an integrated system that involves the distribution of smart watches to monitor the health of vulnerable populations. These devices, which measure blood pressure, heart rate, blood oxygenation, and detect falls, help prevent serious complications and enable rapid intervention. In case of anomalies, the watch sends an alert via radio waves to the healthcare system, triggering mobile health stations.
These mobile stations will be deployed seasonally to the regions most in need, based on detailed data on climate and extreme environmental conditions, such as air quality, extreme temperatures, and other climatic factors. This ensures that medical care is optimized for areas at greatest risk of health problems due to climatic conditions. In addition, the clocks will be made from recyclable materials, promoting the city's sustainability. The system aims not only to improve the efficiency of medical care, but also to offer a response tailored to the needs of each community, preventing health complications and ensuring rapid action when most needed.
projectDetails.details:
EcoPulse – Project Document

1.0 Questions to Be Answered

1.1 What It Does

The project aims to improve access to healthcare and promote sustainability in Uberlândia, focusing on vulnerable areas with limited infrastructure and sensitivity to extreme climate variations.

1.2 How It Works

The system is integrated and involves the distribution of smartwatches to monitor the health of vulnerable populations. These devices measure blood pressure, heart rate, blood oxygen levels, and detect falls. In case of anomalies, the watches send alerts via radio waves to the healthcare system, activating mobile units.

1.3 Benefits

  • Prevention of serious complications through continuous monitoring.

  • Rapid and efficient response with deployment of mobile units.

  • Improved healthcare management and reduced hospital overload.

1.4 Intention

  • Promote sustainability by using recyclable materials in the manufacture of the watches.

  • Ensure efficiency and inclusion in medical care, prioritizing vulnerable populations.

1.5 Impacts

  • Facilitated access to healthcare in regions with limited infrastructure.

  • Encouragement of sustainability through eco-friendly materials.

  • Reduction of severe medical emergencies and social inequality.

1.6 Considered Factors

  • Social vulnerability and extreme climatic conditions (air quality, temperature, rainfall).

  • Seasonal allocation of mobile units based on climate and environmental data.

2.0 Research

2.1 What It Does

The project aims to contribute to the development of Uberlândia, making it more sustainable and healthy. The smartwatch promotes social inclusion in healthcare, prioritizing vulnerable populations and increasing access to health posts.

2.2 How It Works

Watch Description Inspired by modern smartwatches and sphygmomanometers, the watch measures:

  • Blood pressure (Korotkoff sounds)

  • Heart rate (BPM)

  • Blood oxygen saturation (SpO₂)

  • Fall detection

Data is displayed on the screen and via audio, and transmitted via radio to medical systems. The material is recyclable and features an emergency button, audio output, and an inclusive interface for visually impaired users. The battery is rechargeable, and the design prioritizes accessibility and durability.

Alerts and Interventions In emergency situations:

  • The healthcare system receives automatic alerts.

  • Mobile units are dispatched to the location.

  • Care can be provided on-site or referred to a nearby hospital.

Mobile units also operate in regions with extreme climatic conditions, according to NASA data.

2.3 Mobile Units

Adapted vans function as mobile medical units, equipped with examination kits and direct communication with healthcare services. They are operated by interns and medical students in partnership with universities.

2.4 Benefits, Intention, and Impacts

  • Continuous health monitoring.

  • Rapid and precise medical response.

  • Technological and social inclusion.

  • Sustainability and optimization of public resources.

2.5 Considered Factors

  • Social Vulnerability: Identification of areas with limited infrastructure and high climatic risk.

  • Seasonality: Mobile units are allocated according to climate and environmental data to maximize efficiency.

2.6 Tools Used

NASA Resources

  • EU Copernicus Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL)

  • NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC)

  • WorldPop

Partners

  • INPE (National Institute for Space Research)

  • INDE (National Spatial Data Infrastructure – Brazil)

3.0 Chat Research (Complementary Summary)

3.1 What It Does

Promotes a sustainable and healthy city with a smartwatch focused on social inclusion in healthcare.

3.2 How It Works

The watch monitors blood pressure, BPM, SpO₂, and falls, sending data via radio and generating automatic alerts. Manufactured with recyclable materials and an accessible interface.

3.3 Benefits and Impacts

  • Emergency prevention.

  • Rapid and inclusive healthcare.

  • Reduction of inequalities.

  • Environmental sustainability.

3.4 Considered Factors

  • Social and climate vulnerability.

  • Seasonality and environmental data to prioritize interventions.

4.0 Mobile Units – Improvement

Mobile health units, implemented through adapted vans, already exist in Uberlândia, but the proposal is to enhance this infrastructure, making it more efficient in serving vulnerable communities.

4.1 Functioning and Integration

When the watch detects an anomaly, it automatically sends an alert to the healthcare system. The nearest van is dispatched, receiving the data and navigating to the location with real-time information.

4.2 Seasonality and Planning

The distribution of vans will be optimized according to climate risks, such as heat waves and increased pollution, ensuring strategic deployment.

4.3 Equipment and Training

Vans will be equipped with full medical kits, direct communication with hospitals, and trained personnel, ensuring integrated healthcare delivery.

4.4 Benefits for the Community

This enhancement transforms mobile units into continuous connection points between citizens and the healthcare system, preventing severe emergencies and improving service efficiency.

5.0 Links Used and Applications

5.1 Copernicus – UCDB 2024 Visual

European Union (EU) Copernicus Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL)

  • Socioeconomic: Life expectancy increased from 2000-2015 but decreased from 2015-2020, highlighting the challenge of maintaining a healthy and sustainable city.
  • Danger and Risk: Increased risks from 2014-2016, mainly linked to heat waves affecting cardiovascular and respiratory health, potentially causing fainting.
  • Climate: Average annual temperature increased 2.5°C (1970-2010) with projections until 2030, showing the direct impact of climate change on health.
  • Emissions: Increase in pollutant and CO₂ emissions (1975-2020), intensifying the greenhouse effect and respiratory diseases.
  • Healthcare: Average of 6 hospitals per 100,000 inhabitants in Uberlândia (approx. 42 for 760,000 inhabitants), low considering demand.



  • Access: Between 300,000–400,000 people live more than 1 km from a hospital, evidencing difficulty of access in vulnerable areas.

5.2 GHSL – Global Human Settlement Layer

European Union (EU) Copernicus Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL)

 Used to identify vulnerable suburban zones (in yellow), essential for planning mobile unit distribution.

5.3 INPE – Map Catalog

Brazilian Space Research Institute (INPE) Catalogue

Geographic database for evaluating regions of Uberlândia, supporting mapping of social and environmental vulnerabilities.

projectDetails.name: The Day the Sun Messed with Everything.
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, “The Day the Sun Messed with Everything,” is an educational illustrated story designed to explain the effects of solar activity on everyday life in a simple and engaging way. We developed a narrative that follows different characters — a farmer, a pilot, an astronaut, an engineer, and a child — all experiencing the impacts of a solar storm from their unique perspectives.

The project addresses the challenge of making complex scientific phenomena, like solar flares and geomagnetic storms, accessible to children and the general public. By connecting these events to relatable daily situations, readers can better understand how solar energy influences technology, communication, and life on Earth.

This is important because increasing awareness of space weather helps people appreciate the Sun’s power and the importance of science in predicting and protecting our planet from its effects.
projectDetails.details:
Our project, “The Day the Sun Messed with Everything,” is an interactive educational story that demonstrates how solar activity can affect life on Earth. It works by combining storytelling, visual illustrations, and science communication to explain complex phenomena — such as solar flares, magnetic storms, and their effects on satellites, communication systems, and power grids — in a way that is accessible to all ages, especially children.

The main benefit of this project is its ability to transform scientific knowledge into an engaging learning experience. Readers gain awareness of the importance of solar observation and space weather research, while also developing curiosity about science, technology, and environmental awareness.

The intended impact is to promote scientific literacy and help communities understand how solar energy influences everyday technologies — from airplanes and electricity to GPS and internet systems.

We developed the project using Canva for graphic design. The creativity lies in the fusion of storytelling and real-world science — turning a potential global issue into an inspiring, easy-to-understand narrative.

Our team considered clarity, age-appropriate language, cultural inclusivity, and scientific accuracy to ensure the story educates, entertains, and empowers readers to appreciate the Sun’s vital role in our lives.
