node.title: Orbital Token Market
node.excerpt: Inicio.

projectDetails.name: Project Orbital Token Market
projectDetails.summary:
We developed Orbital Token Market, a groundbreaking platform that bridges the real economy of space with blockchain technology, enabling a new era of accessibility and transparency in orbital infrastructure. Our mission is to transform orbital capacity into liquid, tradeable, and accessible assets through tokenization. By registering satellites and converting their available service hours into Real World Asset (RWA) tokens, we create a secure marketplace where companies can monetize unused orbital time, and investors can directly participate in the space economy with clarity and confidence.

The platform provides tools for satellite scheduling, token management, and the creation of investment pools that finance new space projects. Each available satellite hour is tokenized into a digital asset, which can be purchased, traded, or allocated. When the service is consumed, the token is burned, ensuring efficiency, scarcity, and a continuous operational flow. This system establishes a dynamic and sustainable cycle, connecting enterprises, investors, and researchers.

Our platform democratizes space because it makes the next frontier accessible, transparent, and collaborative. Any researcher, company, or individual anywhere in the world can rent satellite time using cryptocurrency tokens, making access to orbital infrastructure no longer restricted to governments or large corporations. Addressing the critical challenge of opening the space economy to global participation.

challengeDetails.title: Commercializing Low Earth Orbit (LEO)
challengeDetails.excerpt: As the commercialization of space rapidly accelerates, the future of business in low Earth orbit (LEO) holds incredible potential, but also presents significant operational, regulatory, and environmental challenges. This new economic frontier invites innovative and sustainable approaches to foster long-term viability and responsible execution. Your challenge is to conceptualize and design a scalable, sustainable, business model, accompanied by a prototype, that explores the unique opportunities LEO offers while addressing the complexities of operating in space. (Joint Agency Satellite Division)

node.title: Plastic Busters
node.excerpt: Sou Gustavo Kim, apaixonado por ciência e tecnologia. E quero explorar o poder dos fungos contra o plástico.Busco pessoas criativas

projectDetails.name: Project Plastic Busters
projectDetails.summary:
Plastics exhibit high resistance to natural degradation, with a half-life that can exceed 600 years depending on their polymeric composition. This persistence poses a significant environmental challenge, as plastics gradually fragment into smaller particles known as microplastics, which display high stability and potential toxicity to living organisms. Recent studies have reported the presence of microplastics in fish and even in human tissues, underscoring the extent of environmental and biological contamination.
Given this global issue of plastic pollution, the development of sustainable and science-based solutions is imperative. Several fungal species have demonstrated notable efficiency in degrading synthetic polymers under optimal conditions, particularly those belonging to the genera Aspergillus, Pestalotiopsis microspora, Zalerion maritimum, Penicillium spp., and Fusarium spp.
This project aims to advance this field of study by employing artificial intelligence tools to identify and assess, on a global scale, environments with favorable conditions for fungal-mediated plastic biodegradation, thereby enhancing bioremediation strategies and promoting environmental sustainability.
projectDetails.details:
This environmental pollution icontinues to increase every day, and while the only current remediation is the use of alternative products, there is still no solution for all the existing pollution. Once developed, this project can greatly assist in combating plastic pollution. The greatest challenge is creating a sustainable world, and using fungi to degrade plastic, even in inhospitable environments, could be the path to the future.
The front-end development was structured based on modular architecture best practices in Python, prioritizing scalability and code clarity. The Streamlit library served as the core of the interface, chosen for its ability to integrate interactive components, dynamic visualizations, and scientific APIs with minimal development overhead.
Communication between the interfaces and backend modules (such as ml_model.py, correlation.py, and data_loader.py) occurs through direct function calls, ensuring an optimized data flow. The interactive map was implemented using Folium and streamlit-folium, incorporating layers from NASA GIBS (Global Imagery Browse Services) to render satellite imagery, allowing users to explore environmental variables such as air quality and altitude.
The Analytical Dashboard was developed with Plotly Express and Matplotlib, displaying performance indicators of fungal activity in the decomposition of different types of polymers. The Predictor module integrates with a machine learning model, providing forecasts of fungal colony behavior when exposed to specific plastic types, based on data stored in an SQLite (.db) database.
The input layer (modules “Insert Plastic” and “Insert Fungus”) was designed to automatically feed data into the database, including field validation and direct integration with analytical routines. The entire application was developed with a focus on usability, efficiency, and digital sustainability, applying the principles of Green Computing within the environmental and scientific scope of the Plastic Busters project.
This pollution continues to increase every day, and while the only current remediation is the use of alternative products, there is still no solution for all the existing pollution. Once developed, this AI can greatly assist in combating plastic pollution. The greatest challenge is creating a sustainable world, and using fungi to degrade plastic, even in inhospitable environments, could be the path to the future.

projectDetails.name: Fire Alert: World Edition
projectDetails.summary: We developed a wildfire monitoring system using real-time data from NASA satellites through the FIRMS platform. The system collects and analyzes data such as geographical coordinates, fire intensity, and detection reliability, calculating the distance to points of interest and classifying fire hotspots by intensity and risk. Additionally, the system displays real-time alerts on a web interface and allows user interaction. Based on the same concept, we created a game, Fire Alert: World Edition, to encourage wildfire fighting in a simple and interactive way. Both projects aim to improve early detection and rapid response to wildfires, contributing to the protection of ecosystems, communities, and facilitating the planning of preventive actions. The importance of these systems lies in creating effective tools for continuous monitoring and raising public awareness about the severity of wildfires.
projectDetails.details:
The system uses real-time data from NASA satellites through FIRMS. Each satellite provides information on fire hotspots, including geographical coordinates, fire power (FRP), acquisition time and date, and detection confidence level. To access the database, the system uses the Map Key provided by NASA, ensuring authentication and authorized access.

The program is written in Python, utilizing libraries such as pandas and numpy for data manipulation and analysis, and requests for HTTP requests. It performs the following processes:

Generation of an area of interest (bounding box) based on the latitude, longitude, and radius provided by the user.

Collection of satellite data for the past N days.

Conversion and standardization of essential columns: latitude, longitude, FRP, intensity, reliability, risk, and distance.

Calculation of the distance between each hotspot and the point of interest using the Haversine formula.

Classification of intensity (Low, Moderate, High), reliability (>40%), and risk (Medium, High).

Sorting and filtering of data to display only reliable hotspots near the monitored point.

Initially, the AI helped create a basic version capable of querying fire hotspots near a coordinate by making requests to the NASA FIRMS API, filtering the data by reliability, and calculating the distance to the central point. Based on user feedback, the AI then suggested parameter adjustments, increasing the alert radius, and adding different confidence levels, making the code more flexible.

In later stages, the AI guided the introduction of multiple satellites, vectorization with NumPy to improve performance, handling missing data, and the creation of additional metrics such as fire intensity and risk based on reliability. Enhancements were also made to the presentation of results, such as sorting by proximity, formatting timestamps, and centering tables, always following the user's instructions to make the output clearer and more understandable.

Finally, the AI assisted in implementing user interactivity and the bilingual translation of the script, maintaining all previous functionalities. Each design decision, each function addition, or logic adjustment was made based on conversations, demonstrating how artificial intelligence can be used to guide and structure the development of a complete project in a collaborative manner.

The processed data is transformed into centered tables with clear headers and professional alignment, making quick interpretation easier. The web interface provides real-time alert visualization, including geographic location, fire intensity, data reliability, risk, and distance from the monitored point.

The system's benefits come from early detection of fire hotspots, enabling rapid responses, continuous and reliable monitoring based on official NASA data, risk assessment based on quantitative and qualitative variables, public availability for managers, companies, and communities, expanding prevention efforts, and potential future integration with emergency response systems.

The project aims to significantly reduce damage caused by fires, protect ecosystems and human communities, increase decision-making efficiency for environmental agencies and private companies, and create business opportunities through the public monitoring platform. Additionally, it contributes to environmental research and provides reliable data for prevention policies and territorial planning.

Moreover, based on the same programming concept, we developed a game called Fire Alert: World Edition. The goal of the game is to encourage global firefighting efforts in an interactive and simple way.

The game features a world map covered with yellow dots, indicating areas prone to fires. As time passes, the dots change from yellow to red, indicating that a fire has started. The player must click on the red dots to put out the fire.

When the game begins, the initial score is 20. Each red dot clicked earns ten points. If a yellow dot is clicked by mistake, five points are lost. The game ends when the score reaches zero.

We used the Scratch website to create the game, using four event blocks with the following functions:

Change the color of the dot from yellow to red over time.

A timer that counts up to five seconds and then resets.

Coordinates described by a custom block.

Increase or decrease the score based on the timer.;

We have five dots, each on a different continent, moving every four seconds within their respective continents. We also programmed the "start" and "play again" buttons to begin and restart the game. The programming forms the basis of our game, and thus mathematical calculations are needed to compute coordinate and time data, ensuring everything in the game happens with precision.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
The development of the code was entirely based on conversations with an artificial intelligence, using ChatGPT as a programming assistant. With each version, the code evolved from suggestions, adjustments, and explanations provided by the model, which interpreted the user's commands and objectives and transformed these instructions into practical implementations.

We also used ChatGPT to translate the texts from Portuguese to English.

projectDetails.name: External Support Structure (ESTU)
projectDetails.details:
External Support Structure (ESTU)

ESTRUTURA EXTERNA DE APOIO

our website:

PROPOSAL: An External Support Structure (ESTU) is a structure built outside the astronauts' habitat that can be used for various purposes, including workshop and storage (the use will depend on the astronauts' needs and available resources). The ESTU was developed for the useful utilization of the three-dimensional cubic structure, material recycled after the inflatable habitat is inflated and secured, to create a new space that serves as support for astronauts to perform tasks, missions, and life in space more efficiently and sustainably.

Workshop - A suitable place for the development of tools and materials using or not using recyclable resources. The workshop will be built in a way that promotes the creation and artisanal development with workbenches, support tables, and spaces for organizing tools.

Warehouse - A suitable place for the storage of any materials developed or brought from Earth that are not essential in the astronauts' habitat for the economy and optimization of astronauts' spaces. The location should be constructed in such a way that the mentioned storage structures are prioritized.

WASTE: Temporary aluminum structure of the inflatable habitat, clothing waste, floor cloths/plates, food packaging (containing aluminum and polyethylene), bubble wrap, packing foam, air cushions for packing, empty CTBs, used PMC plates in packaging, Martian regolith (not waste, but used).

  • Structure - rearranged aluminum from the temporary three-dimensional cubic structure of the inflatable habitat:

(We estimated around 2.6m (3,3 feet) in height at the highest point of the cabin, since it is made with the support poles from the habitat.{ Maybe it will be taller.})

  • Cloth (see below)

PROPOSAL: Multi-purpose protective cloth developed from recyclable material that will be used for external protection of ESTU and other activities, for example:

a) to be used as a floor for the ESTU as well;

b) protect materials added outside the astronauts' habitat and the ESTU as equipment if necessary;

c) can be used as extra protection for astronauts due to its thermal properties and protection against dust and other environmental elements;

Important: the uses of the tarpaulin are unlimited and can vary according to the team's needs.

The original tarp has three layers, designed to form an effective protection.

1. The outermost layer, which will be the most resistant layer, will protect the ESTU from the hostile environment of Mars, keeping stored materials and astronauts safe. The outermost layer, which will be the most resistant layer, will protect the ESTU from the hostile Martian environment, keeping stored materials and astronauts safe. Furthermore, it is the layer that will serve as a barrier against sandstorms, and in the case of using tarps for equipment protection, it is also very important. The materials must be the most resistant ones available.

Materials: aluminum, polyethylene, nylon, polyester. Present in: Food packaging, external packaging, beverage bags, thermal bags, rehydration bags.

How can the joining of the packaging/materials for the creation of the first layer be done: By heating the edges of the plastics to bond them together.

Note: this can be done with a tool similar to an iron or a hair straightener.

Important: This heating must be done at a low temperature to avoid releasing any toxic gases.

2. The middle layer for thermal insulation and extra protection. For human uses or depending on the intended use of the ESTU, temperature is crucial, which is why this layer is important.

Materials: bubble wrap or air bags. Present in: Various packaging. (in some situations, these materials are the packaging themselves.

How the joining of the packaging/materials for the creation of the second layer can be done: By heating the edges of the plastics to bond them together. Note: this can be done with a tool similar to an iron or a hair straightener.

Important: This heating must be done at a low temperature to avoid releasing any toxic gas.

3. The innermost layer that will serve to structure the tarp, in addition to being the least rigid of the layers. In the case of human use or equipment protection, a material like aluminum (present in the first layer) could cause a lot of discomfort or damage to the integrity of the equipment, which is why the fabric layer is quite useful.

Materials: Fabrics such as cotton, cellulose, nylon, polyester. Present in: clothes, dishcloths, disinfectant wipes.

How can the joining of the fabrics for the creation of the third layer be done: By sewing the fabrics together. This can be done with a kit brought by the astronauts themselves or by using small strips of fabric to tie everything together with knots.

After developing the three layers separately, it is necessary to join them.

Ways to join the three layers of the Cloth:

a) Join layers 1 and 3 in such a way that layer 2 remains firmly in the middle without the need to be fixed. How: Heat the entire edges of the first layer and stick it to the third layer so that the second layer stays in the middle.

b) Join all the layers using tape that ensures secure adhesion (to avoid potential problems with the structure of the tarp)

Important: The structure of the three-layer tarp can be rearranged as needed. For example, it may be necessary to have a tarp made only of fabric, so the astronauts could use three layers made only of fabric.

Proposal for the floor of ESTU: A cloth made only with first-layer materials.

PROPOSAL: Modular containers and tables for storage and project fabrication

Cargo transfer bags (CTB's) - Self-storage bags for space missions and come in various size configurations. After emptying a CTB, its shape is suitable for making simple structures.

Blocks - When filled and compacted with Martian regolith, they can become convenient structural blocks for cladding and structuring. They can also be used as seats and other furniture if their interior is filled with foam and other materials.

PROPOSAL: Modular Tables/Shelves for Storage and Project Development

Polymer Matrix Composites (PMC's) - These are materials composed of a thermoplastic or thermosetting resin matrix coated with a fiber that is substantially more resistant than the matrix. In the case of the PMC provided in the mission, which is made of plastic resin and carbon fiber, we can reuse its hardness and strength to produce workbenches and modular furniture for the developing structure.

(In the example, a PMC top is placed on an aluminum structure, serving both as a table and a shelf.) If all the aluminum has been used in the workshop structure, CTB blocks can also be used as a foundation for such tables.

challengeDetails.title: SpaceTrash Hack: Revolutionizing Recycling on Mars
challengeDetails.excerpt: During a hypothetical three-year mission to Mars and back, an eight-person crew would accumulate 12,600 kg of inorganic waste, or trash, including various packaging materials, textiles, and structural materials. This scenario creates a pressing need to recycle available materials, rather than execute the expensive and inefficient processes of transporting additional resources from Earth and/or sending trash back to Earth. As humans prepare to explore unknown worlds in the future, your challenge is to design sustainable systems that could manage, reuse, or recycle inorganic waste (“trash”) that is brought to and/or accumulated on the surface of Mars. (Space Technology Mission Directorate)

node.title: Savoir-faire
node.excerpt: We are a group of 6 friends from the same Computer Science class at UFU (Federal University of Uberlândia).

projectDetails.name: Statistical Weather Analysis and Meteorology Prediction Tool (SWAMP Tool)
projectDetails.summary:
We've developed Savoir-Faire SWAMP (Statistical Weather Analysis and Meteorology Prediction), a web application that provides historical meteorological data and statistical analysis to help users estimate the likelihood of specific weather phenomena for a given day and location.

SWAMP it addresses to the challenge because the tool enables users to create a personalized dashboard to view the probability of certain weather conditions (e.g., temperature, precipitation, humidity, wind speed) for a selected time and place.

SWAMP is particularly useful for anyone planning an outdoor event, such as a vacation, a hike, or a fishing trip, as knowing the chances of adverse weather helps in making more informed decisions.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do or how does it work?

Our project is a web application that provides a probabilistic weather forecast based on historical data. Using NASA's POWER API, it gathers 20 years of climate data for a specific location and date. Instead of predicting the weather in real-time, it applies a statistical model based on the Bell Curve (Normal Distribution) to analyze weather patterns within a seven-day window around the chosen date. The result is a forecast that informs the likely intensity of a weather event (like rain), allowing the user to know if the historical pattern points to a drizzle, a heavy storm, or a day with no precipitation.

What benefits does it have?

The main benefit is providing a much more detailed and useful forecast for event planning. While traditional forecasts offer a percentage chance of rain, our tool contextualizes that chance with its probable intensity. This allows users to make more informed decisions: a high probability of a "drizzle" has a very different impact than a high probability of a "storm." Consequently, the project helps manage expectations and prepare more suitable contingency plans for any outdoor activity.

What is the intended impact of the project?

The intended impact is to empower people to plan events with greater confidence by reducing the uncertainty associated with the weather. By providing a historical perspective on what is "normal" for a given week of the year in a specific location, our tool aims to become a reliable resource for event organizers, travelers, and anyone who needs to plan ahead. The ultimate goal is to lessen the stress of planning and increase the success rate of activities that depend on good weather.

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

For development, we used a modern, performance-focused stack. The frontend was built with React, Tailwind CSS, Shadcn/ui, and Recharts for data visualization. The backend is an API built in Python with the FastAPI framework, served by Uvicorn and Gunicorn. For data processing, we used the Pandas and NumPy libraries. For optimizations, we employed aiohttp for asynchronous requests to the NASA API, orjson for rapid JSON serialization, and an in-memory cache to speed up responses.

How is your project creative?

Our project's creativity lies in its approach to the problem. Instead of competing with real-time weather forecasts, we shifted the question from "Will it rain?" to "Based on the last 20 years, how does the weather typically behave this week?". The application of a well-established statistical model (the Bell Curve) to generate a forecast of likely intensity, based on a vast set of historical NASA data, is an innovative way to extract practical value and insights for event planning—something that conventional forecasting tools do not offer.

What factors did your team consider?

Our team considered several factors. First, technical feasibility aligned with our skills: we chose a web application challenge because the team has strong full-stack development experience. Second, the quality and availability of data, which led us to select a challenge with rich NASA data sources. Finally, performance and user experience were crucial, guiding our technological choices to ensure the application was fast, responsive, and presented the data clearly and intuitively to the end-user.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
No images, videos, audio, or data were generated with AI.

We used Lovable AI as a kickstart for our frontend development. We provided the tool with our original references, screen mockups, and logo to guide the design process. We also detailed the planned functionality, expected UI behavior, and responsiveness requirements. Based on this input, the AI generated a React prototype that served as the foundation for building our application, kickstarting the initial development. Additionally, we used Gemini Pro as a copilot to refine the code, streamline the process, and ensure the proper use of React features with which we were unfamiliar.

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

challengeDetails.excerpt: Witness the pulse of life across our planet! challengeDetails.title: Through the Radar Looking Glass: Revealing Earth Processes with SAR
challengeDetails.excerpt: Like Alice in Wonderland, let’s travel down the rabbit hole to reveal a world that looks like our planet Earth… but not quite! Using synthetic aperture radar (SAR), we can image the world by emitting radar pulses toward Earth and recording the energy that is reflected back after the signals interact with Earth's surface. Your challenge is to download multi-frequency or multi-polarization SAR data for an interesting study area of your choice –e.g., your hometown, a tropical wetland, ice sheet, forest wildfire, flooded neighborhood, volcano eruption, etc.—and use that data to develop hypotheses about the physical drivers operating there. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: ET and Lily - Starborn Girls
projectDetails.summary: We present the story “ET and Lily”, a digital children's book that takes kids and teens on a fun journey to discover what space weather is and how it affects different people on Earth. Using NASA data and accessible explanations, the project offers a solution to the challenge of writing and illustrating a story that explains space weather and its diverse impacts on the people around us and various situations. We believe it is essential for the new generations to learn about scientific topics in a lighthearted way, awakening their curiosity and promoting knowledge. That is why “ET and Lily” was created in order to make this knowledge accessible and easily understandable for everyone, encouraging the little curious to be the great scientists of the future.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do and how does it work?

"ET and Lily" is a children's story that begins when an extraterrestrial researcher falls into Lily's backyard, a curious and dreamy girl who has the desire to become a scientist. Together, they embark on a journey to explore Earth and understand how space weather impacts people's lives and even their own.

The story uses data from NASA, as well as additional information from other agencies and images to explain the events that occur in the story in a light and understandable manner for a young and lay audience. 

The characters travel to various locations around the world to meet new people who can help them understand more about space weather. In this narrative, they learn about what space weather is and how it impacts farmers, photographers, radio stations, and astronauts by interfering with GPS and radio signals and creating auroras borealis and emitting harmful radiation in space. At the end of the story, there is a direct interaction with the reader, encouraging them to take an interest in scientific events that directly affect the planet, such as space weather, as well as in scientific research and the pursuit of knowledge.

What are the benefits?

The project offers a series of benefits by bringing a story that makes complex concepts and real NASA data be understood in a playful and engaging way, in addition to providing authentic learning without losing the fun tone. The story also captivates and offers reflections on how events that seem so distant actually affect all our lives and the importance of studying them.

What do we hope to achieve?

The story was designed to encourage children to see the world more broadly and understand the relationships between natural phenomena and the daily lives of humanity. We hope that readers develop an interest in science and scientific research and, consequently, let them know more about NASA.

What tools were used?

The development of "ET and Lily" involved various tools and resources to ensure the quality of the content and the effectiveness of the project. Among the tools used are:

  • Canva: For the creation of illustrations and visual designs of the story, in addition to being the platform on which the project was made;
  • Ibis Paint: Creation of the characters and flying saucer;
  • Google: Used to access the scientific information utilized and ensure that the scientific concepts addressed in the story are accurate and truthful;
  • Quillbot: Grammar review and translation.

Factors considered in the project development and why is it creative?

  • Natural curiosity of children: We know that children are naturally curious, and we want to take advantage of this characteristic to engage them with scientific topics.
  • Childlike visual aspects: The characters were hand-drawn to bring a more playful and accessible feel, with the intention of creating an emotional connection with the child audience.
  • Educational approach: The story was constructed to be informative without losing its fun character, with the idea that learning about science should be an enjoyable experience.

projectDetails.name: Through the Stellar Gaze
projectDetails.summary:
For the "Stellar Stories" challenge, I developed "Through the Stellar Gaze," a children's storybook that translates complex NASA science into an educational narrative for early readers. The core of my project is a custom AI agent, configured in Gemini with a curated dataset of NASA's resources on space weather. This agent's ability to be continuously updated with new information makes the storytelling dynamic and endlessly customizable.

This project directly addresses the challenge by creating an accessible story about space weather. Its importance lies in making science relatable. Growing up with a passion for stars, I often felt that scientific knowledge and representation were out of reach. "Through the Stellar Gaze" uses AI to bridge this gap, creating relatable narratives that can inspire the next generation, especially young girls, to see themselves in STEM careers and feel empowered to explore their own scientific curiosity.
projectDetails.details:
At its core, this project is about forging a personal connection between children and science.

"Through the Stellar Gaze" is a children's storybook that brings the science of space weather to life for early readers. It works through a unique, AI-assisted workflow. The project's creative core is a custom AI agent I developed in Gemini Pro, which was trained on a curated dataset of NASA resources (articles, transcripts). This agent was configured with a specific persona: an expert astrophysicist skilled in simplifying complex information.

The true innovation lies in this customizable agent. It serves as a dynamic engine capable of generating new, scientifically-grounded stories and characters on demand. This makes the project a replicable framework for science communication, not just a single story.

The primary benefit is making science accessible and engaging. A key asset of the custom agent is its ability to generate diverse characters, allowing children from all backgrounds, cultures, and identities to see themselves front and center in scientific narratives. Furthermore, the story can be easily adapted into other languages, amplifying its impact to a global audience.

The project addresses a gap I experienced firsthand: a world where scientific wonder wasn't always reflected in the stories available to young people. The AI-powered system behind "Through the Stellar Gaze" was designed specifically to bridge this divide. Its purpose is to craft narratives that are not only educational but also deeply empowering. The ultimate goal is to foster a lasting sense of curiosity and show young minds, particularly girls, that they have a central place in the world of science and exploration.

As a solo participant, every decision during development was guided by the goal of maximizing the project's impact and accessibility. This involved a careful balance of three key factors. The story was designed to be visually engaging and simple enough for early readers to ensure it could reach the widest possible audience. However, this simplicity did not come at the cost of accuracy; a primary goal was to maintain scientific fidelity to the sourced NASA data. Finally, inclusivity and representation were a core consideration, leading to a framework that supports diverse characters to make the world of science feel welcoming to every child.

Tools used:

  • Gemini 2.5 Pro: Used to create the custom AI agent, generate the foundational manuscript, produce all core illustrations, and summarize research data.
  • Canva: Used for the final layout and design of the storybook, cover art, text effects, and presentation materials.
  • Google Drive: Used for sharing the final storybook and presentation.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
My intent for this project was to translate complex NASA data into a scientifically-grounded yet accessible children's book. As a solo participant working within a tight deadline, the originality of my approach was to develop a custom AI collaborator to efficiently manage the project's scope.

The process began by me curating a dedicated knowledge base from NASA's available resources for this challenge. I selected key materials, including scientific articles and video transcripts. Using this information, leveraged Gemini 2.5 Pro to build a custom AI agent with a unique persona: an expert astrophysicist who also shared my skills in communication, art, and storytelling, specifically tasked with transforming complex data into a simple, user-friendly narrative.

The custom "gem" was essential for:

Synthesizing the vast amount of technical information into a foundational manuscript, which then served as the basis for my work. My efforts focused on editing and adapting this AI-generated draft to ensure the final narrative quality and alignment with the project's original intent;

Instructed the AI agent to produce a foundational manuscript for a children's book aimed at an audience of early readers, based on NASA's data that I selected;

Authored the detailed prompts that guided the AI in generating the illustrations, defining specific characteristics for each character and the cover art;

All core illustrations and character designs were generated in Gemini 2.5 Pro based on the detailed prompts. I then used a separate graphic design tool to edit the final book cover and page layouts using these AI-generated assets. To ensure transparency, the original illustrations feature a Gemini watermark in the bottom-right corner;

Additionally, I utilized the AI for a final grammatical and stylistic review of the project's texts, using it strictly as a revision tool not for creation to ensure professional clarity.

projectDetails.name: Shark Predictor
projectDetails.summary: We developed Shark Predictor, an interactive web platform that directly addresses the "Sharks from Space" challenge. Our solution integrates diverse satellite and in-situ oceanographic data—including Sea Surface Temperature from MODIS/Terra, chlorophyll from various Earth observation missions, and Ocean Surface Currents from OSCAR via NASA Earthdata, alongside Copernicus Marine data for depth. Using machine learning, the platform analyzes these factors to predict the probability and type of shark presence in a given location, along with an assessment of risk to the human population. This project is vital as it translates complex Earth observation data into actionable insights for marine conservation, scientific research, and public safety.

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earth’s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Tech for good
projectDetails.summary:
Let’s conquer Mars without forgetting those who remain on Earth.
Our project uses NASA’s Earth observation data (MODIS, SMAP, GPM, GLDAS, and VIIRS) to identify municipalities with the highest levels of food vulnerability on our planet.
The Tech4Good Platform enables local governments to register beneficiaries, accredit restaurants, and manage the distribution of food aid through digital vouchers, replacing centralized cafeterias and food baskets.
This model distributes income within local businesses, reduces urban inequality, and creates a virtuous cycle of economic growth in vulnerable communities.
By turning NASA data into actionable intelligence, we help public managers direct resources precisely where they are most needed — promoting social dignity, sustainability, and healthier cities for all.
projectDetails.details:
What it does / How it works:
The Tech4Good Platform transforms NASA’s Earth observation data (MODIS, SMAP, GPM, GLDAS, and VIIRS) into actionable intelligence to identify municipalities with the highest levels of food vulnerability. Local governments register beneficiaries, accredit restaurants, and manage aid distribution through digital vouchers — replacing traditional food baskets and centralized cafeterias.

Benefits and Intended Impact:
This approach decentralizes food access, strengthens local economies, reduces inequalities, and ensures that assistance reaches those most in need. The platform increases transparency, reduces waste, and fosters social dignity by creating a sustainable, data-driven food assistance ecosystem.

Tools, Languages, and Software:
The project integrates NASA APIs, Python, GitHub Copilot, and AI tools such as ChatGPT for data processing, indicator modeling, and dashboard visualization. The system uses QR code technology to validate meals and automate payments to local establishments.

Creativity and Design Considerations:
Tech4Good stands out for connecting space data to urban food policy, transforming global insights into local action. The team prioritized sustainability, scalability, and social impact, ensuring that the model can be replicated by municipalities worldwide.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Our team leveraged AI technologies such as ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot to enhance both creativity and technical execution.

  • ChatGPT was used to design the project’s visual identity (logo and graphics), refine written content, and translate materials from Portuguese to English.
  • GitHub Copilot assisted in building the tool for consuming NASA APIs, calculating vulnerability indicators, and developing the interactive monitoring dashboard.

By combining human insight with AI-powered tools, our team accelerated development, ensured clarity in communication, and delivered a data-driven solution aligned with NASA’s mission to apply space data for social impact.

projectDetails.name: The Chess Forecasters
projectDetails.summary:
The project is a smart, personalized weather forecasting platform designed to support decisions about outdoor events and everyday activities. It collects weather data from trusted sources like NASA, processes it, and transforms it into detailed forecasts for any location worldwide, using machine learning models to generate actionable recommendations and relevant insights.
The solution automates data collection and processing, enabling on-demand forecasts even for locations poorly covered by traditional services. This helps individuals and organizers make safer and more efficient decisions, reducing risks and optimizing resources. The project is important because it democratizes access to high-quality forecasts, improves the user experience, and makes weather technology accessible and practical for everyone.
projectDetails.details: Our project is a web application developed with Next.js, TypeScript, and Node.js, using Python only to build a supporting API. The API connects to the Distance Matrix to calculate distances and routes and integrates the LLaMA model from Meta, which generates natural language explanations to enhance the user experience. Development was carried out in VSCode, prioritizing a modern and scalable architecture, without the use of visual maps in the interface, instead presenting results in reports and interpretive texts. The goal is to provide a creative solution that combines precise route calculations with intelligent AI-driven analyses, positively impacting academic, logistics, and decision-support applications.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools in several parts of our project. AI assisted us in documentation writing and code correction, helping accelerate the development process. Additionally, we integrated Meta’s LLaMA model into our web application to provide climate explanations, and we used Prophet (Python library) for time series forecasting.

projectDetails.name: Exoplanet Classifier ML
projectDetails.summary:
We developed an intelligent exoplanet classification system using XGBoost machine learning to automatically distinguish between real exoplanets and false positives from space mission data. Our solution addresses the critical challenge of validating exoplanet candidates by analyzing 24+ astronomical parameters including transit characteristics, stellar properties, and quality flags.

The system features a modern web interface built with Streamlit, offering both individual object analysis and batch processing capabilities. It supports data from multiple NASA missions (Kepler, TESS/TOI, and K2) and provides real-time classification with probability scores.

This tool is crucial for the astronomical community as it accelerates the exoplanet discovery process, reduces manual validation time, and improves accuracy in candidate screening. By automating the classification workflow, researchers can focus on the most promising candidates for follow-up observations.

The application is deployed online and ready for immediate use by astronomers worldwide, democratizing access to advanced exoplanet classification technology.
projectDetails.details:
**What does it do and how does it work?**

Our Exoplanet Classifier AI is a machine learning system that automatically analyzes astronomical data to distinguish between real exoplanets and false positives. The system processes 24+ observational parameters including orbital periods, transit depths, stellar characteristics, and quality flags from NASA missions. Using XGBoost gradient boosting, it generates probability scores for each candidate, enabling rapid and accurate classification.

**What benefits does it have?**

The system dramatically reduces manual screening time from hours to seconds, improves classification accuracy through consistent machine learning algorithms, and provides standardized validation across different space missions. It democratizes access to advanced classification technology, making it available to researchers worldwide without requiring specialized computational resources.

**What is the intended impact?**

This tool accelerates exoplanet discovery by enabling researchers to focus on the most promising candidates for follow-up observations. It supports the search for potentially habitable worlds and contributes to our understanding of planetary formation and evolution. The system can process thousands of candidates efficiently, potentially leading to new exoplanet discoveries.

**Technical Implementation:**

Built with Python and Streamlit for the web interface, XGBoost for machine learning, and pandas for data processing. The system supports Excel/CSV import, real-time validation, and batch processing. Deployed on Streamlit Cloud for global accessibility with automatic updates via GitHub integration.

**Creative and Innovative Aspects:**

The project combines cutting-edge machine learning with user-friendly design, featuring a space-themed interface with interactive visualizations. We implemented intelligent data validation, dynamic warnings for extreme values, and comprehensive error handling. The system bridges the gap between complex ML algorithms and practical astronomical research.

**Team Considerations:**

We prioritized user experience, data security, and scientific accuracy. The system includes safety warnings about model limitations, protects sensitive training data, and provides comprehensive documentation. We focused on making advanced technology accessible to the broader astronomical community while maintaining professional standards.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
**AI Usage Declaration:**

This project utilized AI tools for documentation and code enhancement purposes only. The core machine learning model, algorithm selection (XGBoost), training process, and scientific methodology were developed independently without AI assistance.

**Specific AI Applications:**

1. **Documentation Generation**: AI was used to translate project documentation from Portuguese to English, including README.md, deployment guides, and user manuals.

2. **Code Comments and Integration**: AI assisted in adding explanatory comments to existing code and making minor integration adjustments for better code readability and maintainability.

3. **Text Enhancement**: AI was used to improve technical writing clarity and structure in documentation files.

**AI Tools Used:**

- ChatGPT/Claude for documentation translation and enhancement

- AI-assisted code commenting for better readability

**Original Work:**

- Complete XGBoost model development and training

- Astronomical data preprocessing and feature engineering

- Streamlit web application development

- Scientific methodology and validation approach

- All core algorithms and machine learning logic

**Compliance:**

All AI-generated content has been reviewed and validated. No NASA branding, logos, or mission identifiers were used in AI-generated content. The scientific integrity and originality of the core project remain intact.

The forum allows for peer review and feedback, enabling an iterative and collaborative design process. Members can browse diverse projects, draw inspiration from different approaches to mission scenarios (like Lunar bases or Mars colonies), and engage in discussions that refine their own ideas.This is important because it shifts space habitat design from an isolated exercise to a community-driven effort. The Hub fosters a creative and educational environment, helping to crowdsource innovative solutions and inspire the next generation of space architects by making their work visible and interactive.
projectDetails.details:
Project Details: Habitat Design Hub

What does it do or how does it work?

The Habitat Design Hub is a web-based community forum designed for sharing, discussing, and iterating on space habitat layouts. It functions as a centralized gallery and collaborative workspace for enthusiasts, students, and professionals in the space exploration field.

How it Works:

  1. Discover: Upon visiting the site, users are greeted with a main feed showcasing a variety of habitat design projects. These are presented in a visually engaging card format, each displaying the project's title, creator, and key tags (e.g., "Mars," "Lunar," "Student Project," "Deep Space").
    • Project Title: A catchy name for their habitat.
    • Summary: A 50-200 word overview explaining the concept.
    • Detailed Description: An in-depth look at features, mission parameters (crew size, duration, destination), and design choices.
    • Images/Renders: An option to upload visual aids for their design.
    • Tags: Keywords to categorize their project for easy filtering and searching.
  2. Engage and Collaborate: Users can click on any project to view its dedicated page. Here, they can read the full details and participate in a discussion through a comment section. They can ask questions, offer constructive criticism, suggest improvements, or simply show appreciation with an upvote/like system. This feedback loop is central to the platform's collaborative nature.

What benefits does it have?

  • Centralized Knowledge Base: It consolidates scattered ideas from various platforms into a single, focused hub, creating a rich, searchable database of habitat concepts.
  • Community Feedback and Iteration: Designers receive valuable feedback from a diverse audience, helping them refine and improve their concepts in ways they might not have considered alone.
  • Educational Tool: It serves as a practical, engaging resource for students learning about engineering, design, and space exploration. They can see theoretical concepts applied in creative ways by a global community.
  • Inspiration and Networking: The platform connects like-minded individuals, fostering a community that can inspire new ideas and potential collaborations.

What is the intended impact of the project?

The intended impact is to democratize space architecture. We want to lower the barrier to entry for contributing ideas to our future in space. By creating an accessible and collaborative environment, the project aims to:

  • Inspire the Next Generation: Motivate students and hobbyists to pursue STEM fields by giving them a platform to showcase their creativity and engage with professionals.
  • Accelerate Innovation: Crowdsource a wide range of solutions to complex challenges in habitat design, potentially sparking novel ideas that influence real-world missions.
  • Build a Global Community: Foster a vibrant, supportive community passionate about humanity's multi-planetary future, united by the shared goal of designing our home in space.

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use?

The project is a web application developed with the following technologies:

  • Frontend:
    • Languages: HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript
    • The platform is hardware-agnostic. As a web application, it is accessible on any device with a modern web browser, including desktops, laptops, tablets, and smartphones. No specialized hardware is required.

How is your project creative?

The project's creativity lies in its social and thematic approach to a technical challenge.

  1. Niche Community Focus: Instead of a generic design tool, we created a specialized social platform. This transforms the solitary act of design into a collaborative, community-driven experience.
  2. Immersive User Interface: The UI/UX is intentionally designed to be futuristic and space-themed. Elements like the "glassmorphism" card style, dark-mode aesthetic, and specialized fonts create an immersive experience that makes users feel like they are part of a forward-thinking, space-age community.
  3. Bridging Disciplines: The Hub creatively merges the technical field of aerospace engineering with creative design, community management, and education, making a complex subject engaging and accessible to a much broader audience.

What factors did your team consider?

  • User Experience (UX): Our primary consideration was making the platform intuitive and easy to use. The process of posting a project and giving feedback needed to be seamless to encourage participation.
  • Accessibility: We aimed for a clean design with readable fonts and a responsive layout that works flawlessly across all devices, ensuring anyone can access the hub from anywhere.
  • Scalability: The technological foundation (Firebase) was chosen to ensure the platform could grow from a small community to a large, active one without performance issues.
  • Positive Community Culture: We considered the need for moderation tools and clear community guidelines from the outset to ensure discussions remain constructive, respectful, and focused on creative problem-solving.
  • Engagement: We included features like upvotes, comments, and tags specifically to drive user engagement and make the platform a dynamic and exciting place to visit regularly.

challengeDetails.title: Your Home in Space: The Habitat Layout Creator
challengeDetails.excerpt: Space habitats are “homes in space” that keep crew members healthy and able to execute their mission. Whether located on a planetary surface or in space, habitats must support critical functions such as waste management, thermal control, life support, communications, power, stowage, food storage and preparation, medical care, sleep, and exercise. Space habitat concepts can involve a diverse array of materials, geometries, and layouts. Your challenge is to create a visual tool that enables users to define a space habitat’s shape/volume and explore possible layout options. (Exploration Systems Development Mission Directorate)

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. “Space weather”—the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earth—can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital children’s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Pale Blue Dot: The Legacy of the Ocean
projectDetails.summary:
Team Titan presents “Blue Point: The Legacy of the Ocean”, an immersive Virtual Reality (VR) experience that transforms raw NASA ocean data into a captivating visual and sound narrative.

Our project addresses the challenge “Deep Dive: Immersive Data Stories from Ocean to Sky” by placing the user in the role of a space explorer whose spacecraft encounters Earth as a potential new home. Through an interactive analysis system, the VR experience takes the user on a journey from space to the ocean depths, highlighting the complex relationship between oceans.
projectDetails.details:
O Pale Blue Dot Project é uma experiência imersiva de Realidade Virtual (VR) que transforma dados científicos oficiais da NASA sobre os oceanos da Terra em uma narrativa interativa. O usuário assume o papel de um viajante espacial de uma galáxia distante em uma missão para encontrar planetas habitáveis, eventualmente descobrindo a Terra. Isso permite uma exploração profunda e imersiva dos processos ecológicos, oceanografia e mudanças ambientais ao longo do tempo.

Benefícios e impacto:

  • Permite a compreensão visual e sensorial do impacto humano nos oceanos e na biosfera.
  • Aumenta a conscientização sobre a degradação ambiental e os desequilíbrios ecológicos, unindo ciência e educação ambiental.
  • Fornece uma experiência única de aprendizado e engajamento em RV, explorando dados complexos de maneira intuitiva e interativa.

Ferramentas, linguagens e hardware/software usados:

  • Unity e C# para desenvolvimento e interações de ambientes de RV.
  • Deep Voice (plug-in do Unity) para narração do copiloto de IA AURA.
  • Blender 3D, 3Ds Max e Autodesk Inventor para modelagem e animação de objetos e hologramas.
  • Meta Quest 2 como o hardware de imersão.
  • Audacity para edição e limpeza de áudio.
  • Python Web Scraping para coletar dados públicos da NASA.
  • Ferramentas de IA, como ChatGPT e Gemini, para suporte narrativo, análise e narrativa dinâmica.
  • Panóplia para séries temporais e visualização de dados geoespaciais.

Criatividade e principais considerações:

  • Combina ciência real, narrativa e interatividade em VR, permitindo que o usuário experimente a experiência exploração espacial.
  • Projetado para ser intuitivo, educacional e esteticamente imersivo, garantindo que os dados sejam compreensíveis e impactantes.
  • A equipe considerou o design narrativo, a precisão científica, a imersão visual e auditiva, a interatividade dos dados e o envolvimento emocional do usuário.
projectDetails.aiReferences: A Inteligência Artificial (IA) foi utilizada como uma ferramenta integral e aceleradora de desenvolvimento em múltiplas fases do nosso projeto. O modelo GPT-5 foi empregado para auxiliar na otimização e estruturação do código C# para a lógica e objetos dentro do Unity. Ele também se mostrou essencial na fase criativa, sendo usado para estruturar a narrativa, integrar dados científicos de forma coesa ao enredo e refinar os diálogos do robô Aura. Paralelamente, o modelo Gemini 2.5 Pro forneceu assistência crucial na análise de dados e web scraping, ajudando a depurar o script Python e a diagnosticar problemas de intervalo temporal para datasets como ICEC, CDHW, CO2F, SURF e WOAQ, garantindo a precisão na coleta de dados históricos. Por fim, para a geração de todos os áudios que contêm as falas da Aura, utilizamos exclusivamente o plugin Deep Voice (Text-to-Speech) do Unity, conforme exigido pelas diretrizes. Em resumo, o uso estratégico da IA permitiu que a equipe maximizasse a originalidade e a execução do conceito principal, otimizando drasticamente o tempo gasto em desenvolvimento técnico e produção de conteúdo.

challengeDetails.title: Deep Dive: Immersive Data Stories from Ocean to Sky
challengeDetails.excerpt: Satellite observations reveal insights about our dynamic home planet to scientists, but people without a remote sensing background often find the stories within these datasets difficult to access. NASA’s open data policy makes these observations available to everyone—scientists and non-scientists alike. Your challenge is to build a short, immersive, virtual reality (VR) experience that leverages NASA’s Earth observation datasets and visualizations to bring stories about our planet’s oceans to life, connecting a broad audience to this data, its beauty, and its impact. Using visuals, spatial audio, and even interactive elements, your VR experience can enable users to dive deeper into Earth’s unfolding ocean story. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: SabIA
projectDetails.summary:
SabIA is a web and mobile application that transforms meteorological information into a visual, educational, and entertaining experience.

The idea is simple: an intelligent thrush bird reacts to real-time weather conditions, changing its appearance and behavior according to the detected climate.

More than just displaying numerical data, SabIA helps the user understand what the weather really means whether the day is too hot, too cold, too humid, or simply uncomfortable.

SabIA aims to bring convenience to the hectic urban life as well as to the cyclical life in the countryside. In large cities, even a small change in the weather can delay traffic, cause flooding, and disrupt outdoor events. In rural areas, however, the weather governs the entire production cycle it is crucial to know in advance when the rainy season will begin in order to plan the best time to plant and harvest, as well as to organize the logistics of purchasing seeds and transporting the crops.
projectDetails.details:
SabIA is an intelligent system powered by a machine learning model capable of predicting the weather for a future date based on the temporal data used during training.

Our system can be divided into three layers:

  • The first layer is the user layer, a front end developed as a one-page application/PWA entirely built with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS. This layer presents a dashboard displaying meteorological data for the selected date, along with our mascot offering tips on what to do under those weather conditions. Additionally, an AI-powered chatbot is available to provide more detailed information about the weather.
  • The second layer is the API layer, written in Python using the FastAPI framework. It exposes endpoints that are consumed by the front end to build its dashboards.
  • The third and final layer is an AI model trained on meteorological data provided by NASA. We adopted a pre-trained XGBoost model specialized in sequential data through the refinement of decision trees. This layer includes specific models for short-term and long-term forecasts.

The project introduces a new approach to handling meteorological data by using AI specialized in sequential data, such as time series of temperature (maximum and minimum) and wind speed. The main goal is to improve long-term prediction accuracy, which can consequently enhance urban life by making it easier to anticipate floods and heavy rain, as well as rural life by helping plan planting and harvesting schedules.

In addition, a mascot was created to act as a virtual assistant, providing advice on how to respond to different weather conditions offering a more empathetic and engaging way to present weather forecasts.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Google Gemini was used to generate the mascot’s images and GIFs, ChatGPT was used to assist with content translation, and CursorAI was used for building the front end and making adjustments to the back end.

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If you’re planning an outdoor event—like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lake—it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of “very hot,” “very cold,” “very windy,” “very wet,” or “very uncomfortable” conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Through the Radar Looking Glass: Revealing Earth Processes with SAR
challengeDetails.excerpt: Like Alice in Wonderland, let’s travel down the rabbit hole to reveal a world that looks like our planet Earth… but not quite! Using synthetic aperture radar (SAR), we can image the world by emitting radar pulses toward Earth and recording the energy that is reflected back after the signals interact with Earth's surface. Your challenge is to download multi-frequency or multi-polarization SAR data for an interesting study area of your choice –e.g., your hometown, a tropical wetland, ice sheet, forest wildfire, flooded neighborhood, volcano eruption, etc.—and use that data to develop hypotheses about the physical drivers operating there. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: UrbanMinds
projectDetails.summary: We created a website that recommends the best sustainable urban development methods for the user’s selected location. The platform focuses on enhancing residents’ quality of life while supporting a fast and sustainable city growth. It is important because sustainable urban development is one of the most pressing issues today, since most urban areas worldwide lack an ecologically sound growth, which is vital for improving people's quality of life and other essential aspects.
projectDetails.details:
We created a website that features a map integrating NASA Earth Science data to recommend the best sustainable urban development methods for the user’s selected location (currently limited to a few cities). The platform focuses on enhancing residents’ quality of life while supporting fast and sustainable city growth. We intend to bring benefits in people's quality of life and urbanization, since it can help with useful information about pollution, helping the development of cities without destroying nature. Used softwares and tools: NASA Worldview, NASA GIBS (Global Imagery Browse Services), OpenStreetMap, Web Map Service (WMS), Canva, Visual Studio Code, Google Docs, Vercel. Used coding languages:JavaScript, HTML, CSS and Python, and Artificial Intelligences were used to assist the coding. Our project is innovative as it provides practical and dynamic solutions, addressing complex issues related to urban infrastructure. This approach enables citizens to actively participate in identifying problems and to request that the appropriate authorities implement effective solutions.

The interactive map, in conjunction with our artificial intelligence, Aurora, facilitates interaction between citizens and the city. This is an interactive website focused on solving social issues, where users can influence local challenges, while solutions are generated by a proprietary artificial intelligence system.

Our team primarily focused on practicality in problem-solving, as well as on the ease of use and integration of user-provided information into the interactive map. Our starting point was the need to establish a connection between governmental action and individual engagement, with the goal of building more structured and sustainable urban spaces.

challengeDetails.title: Data Pathways to Healthy Cities and Human Settlements

node.title: Urbmind
node.excerpt: Our diverse team brings together three passionate developers, a legal professional, a UI/UX designer, and a data analyst all united as technology enthusiasts and lifelong learners. As professionals and students, we're committed to making a meaning...

projectDetails.name: Project Urbmind
projectDetails.details:
Aqui está uma versão estruturada, pronta para você adicionar fotos no final de cada tópico. Mantive a relevância científica, o peso dos impactos e deixei os locais para inserir imagens bem definidos.

Urbmind

Natural events are inevitable and can cause tragedies and enormous losses. With technology, we can predict risks, reduce damage, and transform response into prevention.

What the project does

Climate change poses growing challenges for cities.

It affects urban infrastructure... and people's very quality of life.

To address this scenario, we developed a solution that combines data provided by NASA to predict natural disasters in real time.

Our system not only identifies flood and climate catastrophe risks, but also generates safe escape routes and sends automatic notifications to authorities—Fire Departments, Civil Defense, City Hall, and Military Police.

This project takes an innovative approach, combining climate change analyses provided by NASA itself, soil permeability and relief maps, and predictive analytics to suggest escape routes to avoid potential natural damage. Its reach is broad and directly benefits a large audience, enabling urban managers and planners to make quick, data-driven decisions.

The result is clear: we reduce human and material losses, preserve the environment, and promote sustainable urban growth.

It's technology that saves lives today... and builds safe cities for the future.

Data Acquisition

  • Sentinel-2 Images: RGB, NIR, and SWIR bands with high spatial resolution.
  • SRTM Data: elevation, slope, roughness, and aspect for topographic analysis.
    All data are aligned in the same CRS and grid for pixel-by-pixel analysis

Colored terrain visualization derived from the SRTMGL1 Digital Elevation Model. Each color represents different altitudes, facilitating the interpretation of terrain morphology, valleys, plateaus, and higher elevation areas. This representation provides a detailed view of the landscape, allowing for precise identification of natural drainage patterns, depressions, and areas prone to water accumulation. By highlighting subtle changes in elevation, it supports hydrological analysis, urban planning, and environmental monitoring. Urban planners and engineers can use these visualizations to assess flood risk, optimize infrastructure placement, and design effective stormwater management systems. Additionally, combining this elevation data with other geospatial layers, such as land cover and satellite imagery, enables comprehensive spatial analysis and decision-making for sustainable development and disaster mitigation.

Multispectral Compositions

  • Atmospheric Penetration: highlights urban areas and water bodies.
  • False Color: precise identification of vegetation and plant cover.
  • NDWI: detection of wet areas and water bodies.

Multispectral composition processed from Sentinel-2 L2A imagery with Atmospheric Penetration enhancement, highlighting urban areas, water bodies, and vegetation zones. This technique improves the visibility of elements hidden by dense vegetation, shadows, or atmospheric particles, allowing for a clearer and more accurate interpretation of land cover. By enhancing the contrast between natural and built-up surfaces, it enables detailed land use analysis, identification of impervious surfaces, and detection of potential flood-prone areas. The imagery supports urban planning, environmental monitoring, and infrastructure development by providing actionable insights into how terrain, vegetation, and urbanization interact. Furthermore, when combined with topographic and hydrological data, this multispectral analysis becomes a critical tool for predictive flood modeling, risk assessment, and sustainable city management, ensuring that decision-makers have precise spatial information for proactive interventions.

Elevation Models and Morphometric Analysis

  • Hillshade, Slope, and Aspect: enable visual analysis of topography.
  • Flatness and Smoothness: identify flat or rough terrain.
  • Flow Accumulation Proxy: simulates natural drainage and water accumulation.

Flood History

Geolocated CSV containing latitude, longitude, rainfall intensity, and dates of past events.
Used for risk adjustment in areas near historical events.

Calculation of Hydrological and Urban Indices

  • TWI (Topographic Wetness Index): identifies areas that accumulate water.
  • Imperviousness: combines band brightness and NDWI to map impervious areas.
    Each index is assigned a calibrated weight: TWI and Imperviousness have higher relevance for flood risk.

Dynamic Integration with Rainfall Data

Final flood probability calculated based on:

  • Rainfall intensity (mm/h)
  • Rainfall accumulation (mm)
  • Event duration
  • Proximity to historical events
    Result is a flood risk score calibrated between 0 and 1.

Examples of Calculations and Analyses


Sentinel-2 RGB bands are carefully aligned to the DEM grid, ensuring precise pixel-by-pixel correspondence between optical and topographic data. From these bands, essential indices are calculated: NDWI, highlighting wet areas and water bodies; NDBI, identifying urban and built-up regions; and Impervious, estimating impervious surface presence. These indicators are normalized to standardize their scales and combined with topographic metrics such as TWI (Topographic Wetness Index) and Flow Accumulation, which assess the terrain’s natural tendency to accumulate water and potential drainage flow. Each indicator is weighted based on its physical relevance and impact on flood risk, resulting in a flood susceptibility score that provides a quantitative and spatially detailed view of the most vulnerable areas, supporting urban planning, disaster prevention, and water resource management.

Automation of Data Collection and Storage

Data are constantly updated and stored in real-time on Supabase. N8N automates the collection of weather information from the weather forecast API, recording rainfall, intensity, and duration in the database. This data is available for the back-end to process and calculate the flood probability at each city point, ensuring the front-end displays accurate, up-to-date alerts for users.

Strategic and Societal Impact

The application interface where the user can directly access flood alerts generated by the model. The interactive dashboard displays the city map with highlighted risk zones, colors indicating flood probability, and detailed information on rainfall intensity and duration. Users can explore different areas, view risk statistics, and receive real-time alerts, enabling rapid decision-making and preventive planning.

Benefits

  • Safe Urban Planning: identifies risk areas and guides urban expansion away from vulnerable regions, ensuring that new developments are situated in safer locations and reducing long-term exposure to floods.

Natural Disaster Reduction: helps prevent human and material losses by anticipating flood-prone areas, enabling timely interventions and community preparedness.

Environmental Protection: supports the preservation of riverbanks, green spaces, and fragile ecosystems, maintaining biodiversity and mitigating erosion.

Water Resource Management: facilitates efficient control of floods, dams, canals, and drainage systems, optimizing infrastructure and resource allocation.

Early Warnings: provides real-time information for alerts and evacuations before critical events, enhancing public safety and response effectiveness.

Resilient Infrastructure: allows for the design of buildings, roads, and urban utilities considering actual flood risk, increasing durability and reducing maintenance costs.

Interactive Visualization: users can explore dynamic maps with detailed flood risk information, overlaying multiple datasets for informed decision-making and spatial planning.

Reduced Public Costs: aids in prevention strategies, lowering expenses associated with repairs, emergency responses, and recovery in flood-affected areas.


Urbmind Platform Features

URBMind is an advanced urban analysis platform that predicts flood risks and climate-related hazards in real time, providing strategic support for critical decision-making in safe and sustainable city management.

Key Features

  • Location Search and Personalized Alerts: users can search any address or coordinate and receive instant alerts if there is a flood risk, ensuring rapid response and damage prevention.
  • City-wide Alert Dashboard: clearly displays all active alerts, highlighting risk zones and providing detailed information on intensity, duration, and probability of critical events.
  • Lab Section: allows users to simulate climate and rainfall scenarios by adjusting intensity and duration, evaluating vulnerability in different areas and anticipating potential disasters.
  • Urban Planning Support: provides precise data and analyses to guide urban expansion, infrastructure projects, and construction planning, contributing to resilient and sustainable cities.
  • Interactive Visualization and Real-Time Data: dynamic maps integrating elevation, soil permeability, and flood history data, allowing detailed exploration of high-risk areas.
  • Integration with Meteorological and Historical Data: combines rainfall forecasts, topography, and historical events to generate flood probabilities, enabling effective preventive planning and action.
  • Future Safe Route Support: planned evolution of the platform will provide safe evacuation routes during critical events, integrating risk analysis and topography to guide movement during emergencies.

URBMind is more than an alert tool — it’s a strategic platform that transforms complex data into actionable decisions, reducing human and material losses, protecting the environment, and promoting safe urban development.
